origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Media Resources Center.

did.unittitle: Media Resources Center (University of Michigan) films and videotapes 1930s, 1948-1986
did.abstract: The television production studio and media services unit of the University of Michigan, commonly referred to as "Michigan Media." It was formed in 1978 through the merger of the university Television Center and the university Audio-Visual Education Center. The Television Center began producing educational programs for broadcast on commercial and public stations in 1950. The Audio-Visual Education Center produced films for the university and operated a film distribution library. The Media Resources Center closed in 1986. The collection consists of documentary type film and video and film and video of television programs produced by the Media Resources Center and its predecessors.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The Michigan Media films and videotapes were transferred in July 1988 through Jo Wenk and George Williams. [Donor # 4408.].

accruals.p: No further additions to the collection are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The films and videotapes are open for use. Special arrangements may be required to view some formats.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan except for a few films not produced by the Media Resources Center.

prefercite.p: [item], Media Resources Center (University of Michigan) films and Videotape , Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Media Resources Center, commonly referred to as "Michigan Media," served as the University of Michigan's television studio and media services unit. Michigan Media was created in 1978 through the merger of the university Television Center and the university Audio-Visual Education Center. The University of Michigan Television Center (TVC), founded in 1950, produced television programs for broadcast on commercial and educational television stations. Although it never operated its own on-the-air television station, the TVC developed a unique "network" by distributing film and videotape of programs for broadcast by local stations across the country.

The Audio-Visual Education Center (AVEC) was formed out of the university Extension Division's Visual Education Bureau. Originally it was primarily a film distribution unit, providing instructional films to the state's elementary and secondary schools and a variety of adult organizations. As the Visual Education Bureau's activities began to center more on serving the university campus, an autonomous Audio-Visual Education Center was created. The AVEC produced and distributed instructional films as well as promotional films for the university. It also produced films on a contract basis for non-university clients.

Michigan Media also provided closed-circuit and other television services for the university, produced films about the university, collected archival film footage of university events, and provided consultation, maintenance and technical support services for media projects in other university units. In addition to television production, Michigan Media was responsible for the AVEC film distribution library and for increased special project film production. Michigan Media was disbanded in 1987 after a unit review and its functions were eliminated or distributed to other university units.

The University of Michigan Television Center and, later, Michigan Media were widely recognized as pioneers in the development of educational television programming. Along with Johns Hopkins, Michigan was one of the first universities to produce educational programs. The TVC developed the concepts of the "telecourse" and the "trigger film." Over the years, Television Center and Michigan Media productions won numerous awards from professional organizations and film festivals.

The Television Center's first facilities were located in the Speech Department offices in Angell Hall. In 1951/52 the TVC occupied rooms in South Quad and set up a temporary closed-circuit studio in an Angell Hall classroom. The TVC's first working studio was established in the former Dolph Funeral Home building at 310 Maynard Street in Ann Arbor in January 1954. The studio and offices were moved to the Argus Building on West 4th Street in Ann Arbor in 1978.

The university's first experience with television production involved the broadcast of student dramas on WWJ-TV, Detroit on an irregularly scheduled program entitled "On Camera." The plays, written and acted by UM students and directed by faculty, were rehearsed on campus. Actors and sets were then taken to WWJ's studios for the live broadcast. Nine plays were televised between 1948 and 1953. Several UM faculty members had also participated in the WWJ produced series "University of the Air."

In the summer of 1950 officials of WWJ proposed to UM president Alexander Ruthven and a group of faculty that the university participate in production of a series of television programs to be called "The University of Michigan Hour." The station guaranteed the university one hour of air time each week on Sunday afternoon and proposed to pay participating faculty members. The station attached two conditions to the offer: that some form of college credit be awarded and that a tuition fee be charged to each registered viewer.

A special university committee considered and accepted WWJ's proposal in September 1950. Garnet Garrison was appointed to the newly created post of Director of Television. Garrison had received a master's degree in speech from UM and then worked in New York for NBC radio. He also taught radio announcing at Columbia University. In 1947 Garrison had accepted a position in the UM Department of Speech. He would be the guiding spirit of University of Michigan television for more than twenty years.

Production of UM Television Hour programs began in 1950. The first program aired November 5, 1950. In accord with WWJ's wishes, the one hour of air time was divided into three twenty minute segments: a liberal arts program running for fourteen weeks, a practical living program to run seven weeks, and a weekly "showcase for the university." The term "telecourse" was coined to describe the programs of the first two segments. Each of the telecourses was to feature a UM faculty member and was to be aimed at an adult audience. It was decided not to offer regular university credits for the telecourses but rather to provide each registering viewer with a certificate of participation. A minimal registration fee was charged and each registrant was provided a course outline and other supplementary material.

The third segment of Television Hour was named the "Teletour." It was designed to be a "weekly invitation to the people of Michigan to visit one of the many institutions of the university." The teletours were usually broadcast from the WWJ studios with a faculty or staff member using a variety of props and visual aids to describe some university institution or activity. Approximately once a month the WWJ remote truck came to Ann Arbor and the teletour was broadcast live from campus.

The telecourse programs were written by the participating professors and TVC staff. Rehearsals were conducted in the TVC facilities in Angell Hall. On Sunday morning, stars, staff, and props were transported to Detroit for the live broadcast from WWJ's studio. Because the telecourses were done live without recording equipment, no film record of the original telecourses exists. Later, several telecourses were redone and recorded on kinescope film.

Other commercial stations soon expressed an interest in broadcasting UM programs. In September 1951 stations WJIM in Lansing and WKZO in Kalamazoo began simultaneous broadcast of the live WWJ programs via a microwave relay hookup.

Station WOOD approached the Television Center with a proposal to begin broadcasting a second series of live programs from its studio in Grand Rapids. The station offered to provide one half-hour of air time on Saturday afternoon but insisted that the series consist of original productions, not rebroadcasts of WWJ programs. WOOD wanted individual programs of general interest that were not part of a "telecourse." The TVC and WOOD agreed on a format and began broadcasting a series of independent programs under the title "Understanding Our World" in March 1952. These programs were developed and rehearsed at the UM campus and then broadcast live from WOOD studios.

A third request for TVC programming came in 1953 from WPAG, the UHF station in Ann Arbor. The station requested two and three quarters hours of non-commercial programming each week. An arrangement was reached whereby the TVC provided studio facilities, equipment, and technical assistance and the UM Speech Department provided programming and student staff as part of its television production courses. The WPAG programming was intended to serve as an on the air laboratory for speech students interested in television production. Several series were broadcast including community and university news, interviews with local and university personalities, and programs aimed at elementary school children. Approximately 340 programs were broadcast from October 1953 to the spring of 1957 when WPAG went off the air. Only a few of these programs were recorded on film.

The format of the UM Television Hour was modified in the fall of 1952. The telecourse portions of the TV Hour were expanded to one half-hour each. The Teletour segment was moved to a new time slot at 5:45 Saturday evening. This program, now 15 minutes long, was renamed "Michigan Reports" (Series H). Beginning in the fall of 1955 the name was changed again to "Accent: Michigan Report." It was broadcast under that name through 1961 when the program was discontinued. Throughout, the series served as a public relations program for the university, showing the public the variety of activities taking place at the University of Michigan.

The telecourse programs were discontinued in April 1954. Declining numbers of registrants was one factor prompting the abandonment of TV programs for which certificates of participation were issued. Other universities had begun to offer television courses for full college credit under the term telecourse. Michigan did not wish to be associated with these for-credit courses and therefore stopped issuing certificates of participation and dropped the use of the designation telecourse.

Thereafter the Television Hour consisted of two half-hour programs of general interest. The first was a series of multi-part programs of from five to thirty segments. The programs generally featured university faculty discussing and presenting material on topics such as medicine and health, national and international affairs, science, history, and other academic subjects. Some 130 different programs were broadcast between 1954 and 1980.

The second portion of the TV hour was given over to the "Understanding Our World" series (Series B) originally created for station WOOD. Though there were several multi-part programs, the series generally consisted of self-contained programs. The programs often featured UM faculty but also included local, national, and even international personalities. The format of the programs included interviews, panel discussions, demonstrations, and documentaries. Over 800 individual programs were broadcast between 1954 and 1980 covering a wide variety of subjects.

The TVC developed a unique network through which UM programs were broadcast over commercial and public stations across the country. The first UM television network was the "live" hook-up of stations WJIM and WKZO to carry the programs broadcast from the WWJ-TV studios. Completion of the Maynard Street facilities on the UM campus and purchase of a kinescope camera allowed the TVC to produce and record programs in its own studio. The kinescope process recorded the "live" television signal on 16 millimeter film. Copies of the film were made and distributed through the mail to local television stations for broadcast at a time of their choosing. A two-inch videotape recording machine was acquired in 1963, permitting distribution of TVC programs in both film and videotape formats.

By the mid-1960s more than 120 television stations had broadcast TVC programs. Stations joined and left the network at various times but distribution of UM programs remained high until the mid-1970s. By that time the development of the public television system and declining demand for educational programming from commercial stations combined to weaken the market for TVC programming.

The TVC was also involved in special project programming and non-broadcast film production as well as in providing media services to other campus units. Significant special projects included re-creating and recording several telecourses for the Educational Television and Radio Center (ETRC), production of programs for the Midwest Project for Airborne Television Instruction (MPATI) and the Medical Television project.

The ETRC, a Ford Foundation sponsored center to promote development of television as an educational medium, provided funding for the TVC to re-create and record on kinescope film three of the telecourse programs and to develop several new programs. ETRC then distributed the kinescopes to educational television stations throughout the country. The TVC videotaped approximately 100 programs for MPATI, a Purdue University-based project that broadcast educational programming over a six-state area via an aircraft with on-board video broadcasting capabilities. Among TVC productions for MPATI were a 64-part series on American literary history titled "From Franklin to Frost," intended for use in high schools, and an elementary Spanish course.

The TVC cooperated with the Medical School to develop the capacity for closed-circuit broadcasting and recording of surgical and diagnostic procedures for use in Medical School courses. Similar projects were undertaken for the Law School, Zoology Department, and other university units. The TVC also produced public relations films for the university and a variety of instructional films not intended for broadcast use.

An innovative concept developed by Michigan Media was the "trigger film." These were short, open-ended dramatic vignettes designed to illustrate some problem or conflict situation and to promote discussion among the viewers. Trigger films were produced on a variety of topics including teenage driving, drug abuse, aging, and dormitory living. The trigger films were recognized with an Osella award from the 1969 Venice International Film Festival.

In 1959 the TVC began to compile what it called a "university film archives." The TVC filmed many university events including awards ceremonies, building groundbreakings and dedications, retirement banquets, graduations, athletic events and marching band performances, homecoming and other social activities, student protests, visits by dignitaries, and general footage of campus buildings and scenes. This archival film was intended in part to provide stock footage for television and film production, but was also a conscious effort to document the university through film.

When the TVC was founded in 1950 it was placed under the administrative control of the director of University Relations. A Broadcasting Committee oversaw the activities of the TVC. The TVC was headed by a director of Broadcasting, a position held by Garnet R. Garrison from 1950 to 1958. In 1958 the director's responsibilities were expanded to include management of the university radio service. Hazen Schumacher was then placed in charge of television operations as associate director of Television. Schumacher became director of Broadcasting upon Garrison's retirement in 1973.

A major reorganization of media services occurred in 1978. The Television Center was merged with the Audio-Visual Education Center to form the University of Michigan Media Resources Center, commonly referred to as Michigan Media. The AVEC developed out of the broadcasting service of the university Extension Service. It had produced filmstrips, audiotapes, and films for use both within and outside the university. Some AVEC films were made for broadcast but most were intended for use by schools, community groups, and other organizations. AVEC had also developed a large film lending library to serve the university, schools, and community organizations.

Michigan Media provided a variety of media services for the university ranging from film production to consulting, engineering services, equipment service and repair, film and tape duplication, and classroom instruction. For a short time it was also the university computer repair service.

In the early 1980s the original television production was scaled back considerably as the demand for educational programming was increasingly met by educational television stations and commercial production companies. Michigan Media also experienced a significant downsizing imposed during the university's fiscal crisis of the early 1980s.

Michigan Media underwent a university review in 1986. The review panel recommended that MM be retained but that its structure and function be significantly modified. Ultimately, however, it was decided that Michigan Media should be disbanded and its functions eliminated or distributed to other units. The television studio and other media production facilities and staff were divided between the College of Literature, Science and the Arts and the Center for Research on Learning and Teaching. The film and video library was placed under the management of the Undergraduate Library. Michigan Media formally ceased to exist on June 30, 1988.

Some Michigan Media scripts and other paper records had been transferred to the Bentley Library between 1968 and 1978. The remainder of the Michigan Media records were transferred to the Bentley in 1988.

arrangement.p: The films and videotapes are organized by series established by the Media Resources Center. Within each series the films are organized either by production number assigned by the Center (in many cases this was the negative number and are roughly chronological) or alphabetically by title. Each item is identified by a title and a unique number comprised of the collection identifier, the series initial or abbreviation, and a sequential number (sometimes the number were assigned by Michigan Media, in other cases the number were assigned by archivists during processing of the collection).

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan Media Resources Center Films and Videotapes collection consists of "archives" film footage produced or collected by the Center and television programs and films produced by the Center. The "archives" films are divide into three series; Archives Film (Series AF), Film File (Series AF) and Audio-Visual Education Center Film File Series AVEC Film File. The television programs are organized based on the

The "archival films": consist of documentary style, 16mm film footage of a variety of University of Michigan events, buildings, and personalities. The series originated in 1959 when the Television Center began a project to create a "university film archives." Some of this footage was shot for the purpose of being incorporated into television programs, but much of the filming was done simply to create a film record of the university. Filming was done on a regular basis through about 1972. After that date the Michigan Media collection includes comparatively few "archival" films.
The subject matter of the archival films falls into several broad categories:

list.item:
Series AF -- Archives Films and Series FF -- Film File
Ceremonial - including footage of awards ceremonies, inaugurations, graduations, building groundbreakings and dedications
Campus scenes - buildings and construction sites, students on the Diag, and general activity on campus
Athletic events and marching band performances
Student activities -- including protests, fraternity/sorority activities, homecoming, course registration, and social events.
Faculty and administrator interviews
Visiting dignitaries and participants in special programs and conferences on campus.
Films collected by the Television Center - these include several films from the 1920s and 1930s

Series AVEC Film File
Original footage shot for use in Audio-Visual Education Center films

scopecontent.p: Films in the three archival series range from a few minutes to more than an hour in length. The films may be negatives, original positives, or work prints. Some are identified as "trims," i.e. original footage edited out of finished productions. The work prints have often been cut and spliced and portions may be missing. Several titles were originally recorded on either two- or one-videotape reels or directly on 3/4-inch videotape cassette.

The early films, ca 1953-ca.1963, are generally black and white. After 1963 color film is more common. Many of the films, especially, from the early years, are silent. For some of these there are accompanying 16mm magnetic sound tracks or 1/4-inch reel-to-reel audio tapes.

The film description part of the finding aid is arranged by series film number or titles. Film numbers were assigned by the Television Center in an approximate chronological order. The description of individual films is based on a card File created by the Television Center and on a viewing of each film by Bentley staff.

The descriptive record for each film includes the film number; title; date; a brief summary of the content of the film; a listing of significant persons appearing in the film; and technical information on the color, sound, polarity, and length of the film.

The films are stored in canisters, usually on a core rather than a reel. A film number generally refers to an individual film title. There is sometimes more than one film number in a canister and occasionally more than one film number on a single reel or core. Alternate versions of a title are indicated by a lower case letter.

The Television Center gave the films titles which are more or less descriptive. These titles have been retained except for a few instances in which a more descriptive title was assigned or in which a uniform title was created for all parts of a multi-reel film. The individual reels of multi-part titles are designated by a lower case letter, e.g. 98a, 98b, 98c. For some titles the may be more than one film, possibly a negative, positive, work print, or other version. A few tittles have been digitized and are available on DVD and streaming files.

The listing for each film or program in includes a Title, date of production, and abstract/summary of the content of the film and ,when available, the names of persons or organizations featured in the film. University of Michigan faculty and staff are identified by departmental or administrative affiliation (e.g. Peter Gosling, UM-Geog. A list of abbreviations used is included in the Additional Descriptive Data Section of this finding aid.) Technical information for the films is provided in the format: Original: 16mm film, pos, b/w, sil, 343, 00:09:35. The order of the information is:
Format -- film / videotape / magnetic sound track
Polarity -- neg (negative) /. Pos (positive) / wp (work print)
Color -- b/w or color
Sound -- silent / sound / sof (sound on film)/ at (accompanying 1/4-inch audiotape)
Length -- expressed in feet (footage value is sometimes an estimate)
Running time -- in the form 01:33:25 (hours:minutes:seconds)
(in cases where there are several versions of a title, there may be multiple values for each category)

The Television Programs consist of 16mm kinescope films and two-inch and 1-inch videotapes of programs produced by the Center for distribution to commercial and educational television stations. The collection represents only a portion of the television programs produced by the Center. There were no extant copies of some programs when the library acquired the collection.

The television programs are organized by series created by the Center. The series for the most part reflect different type of programming the Center produced, from the earliest "telecourses" to the independent programs produced under the title "Understanding Our World". to the multi-part programs that were the core of the "University of Michigan Television Hour. See the History section for details on the different series.

The description for individual programs includes the title and date of the program, a unique id number, and an abstract of the content of the program with listing of the host and guests on the program. A program may exist in one or more formats: kinescope negative, kinescope positive and 1-inch or 2-inch videotape. Technical information for each program is recorded in the format16mm kinescope film, neg. #511, Pos. #665, 2-inch video #458. (the negative number was treated as a production and for some programs recorded originally on videotape a negative was not actually produced). The television programs were generally either twelve, fifteen or thirty minutes in length Most are black and white and all have sound.

In 2009 a selection of television programs and films and tapes were digitized. for each tape or film selected a preservation Beta SP tape was made as well as a DVD use copy and a streaming file (mpeg4 and Flash). For some films a high resolution digital copy was made as well (mpeg2). The finding aid lists the original format(s) and the derivative formats for the digitized items.

scopecontent.p: The AVEC (Audio-Visual Education Center) footage series consists of film footage shot by or acquired by the Center for use in films it produced.

did.abstract: Aerial shots of UM campus, Detroit lakefront, Ford plants, Locks of Sault Ste. Marie, and Great Lakes.
Footage of a UM pottery class and painting class, shot of sculptor Tom McClure at work and his modern sculpture in Dearborn. Features: Tom McClure
Footage from the UM Marching Bands half-time performance honoring the Phoenix Memorial Project.
Footage of football crowds outside and inside Michigan Stadium, shots of the press box, vendors, and scoreboard.
Shots of a number of Central Campus buildings including Law School, women's dorms, East Quad, Engineering Arch, Alumni Hall, Union, Hospital, Health Services, Hill Aud., East Medical, and the Diag.
Shot of "Michigan Daily" headline on graduation story, faculty entering stadium tunnel in ceremonial garb, graduates entering stadium, various commencement scenes and crowd shots.
Footage of professors and students in engineering and French classes.
Close-up of a male student taking an examination, getting graded exam back, and a close-up of the "D" grade.
Footage of construction sites on North Campus and at the Union.
Footage of the speech clinic's sound control room and of a girl in the clinics soundproof booth.
Footage of the laboratories and workshops of the UM Engineering Research Institute, the UM wind tunnel, and other engineering labs.
Footage of UM football games from 1969(?) season.
Film of plays from UM football games during 1969(?) season.
Footage of plays from UM football games during 1969(?) season.
Footage of freighters and ore carriers in the locks, ice bound ore carriers moored for winter, shots from aboard an ore carrier, and shot of ore ship on lake.
Shots of a law professor in his office working with research material, also shot of an elderly reception secretary in an old office area and a man reading a letter at his desk.
Footage of UM President Harlan Hatcher.
Footage of the locks in operation, the lockmaster, and a working model of the locks.

Footage of students and professors working in the Aeronautical Engineering Lab including shots of equipment, students working on aircraft guidance system, and on computers. (Filmed for "First Hundred Years" engineering centennial.)
Footage of male students in a dorm room, studying, unpacking and setting up room, talking with visitors.
Footage of UM Marching Band performing, several high school marching bands, and football team entering stadium.
Footage of UM Marching Band performing and of crowds in Michigan Stadium.
Footage of students watching indoor sports event.
Footage of UM ROTC unit in classroom and in drill formation.
Footage of the UM television studio, control room, cameras, stage and equipment, also shot of WUOM radio studio.
Footage shot in the pharmacy dept. of the UM Health Services for the film "Health is a Circle", also includes shots of a doctor's office and records office.
Footage of a doctors' conference at UM Health Services.
Footage of UM Marching Band performing in Michigan stadium and shots of the crowd.
Footage of women's golf practice with woman instructor, also tennis, volleyball, archery, and field hockey practice.
Footage of UM wrestling matches.
Footage of UM wrestling matches and shots of the crowd.
Footage of UM wrestling matches.

Shots of various buildings and locations on Central and North Campus, including the Union, President's House, Graduate Library steps, students on steps of Angell Hall, Michigan League, and Burton Tower.
Football game footage, majorettes, crowd shots, cheerleaders, and Marching Band.
Aerial of Central Campus.
Footage of UM Marching Band performing at Northwestern football game, crowd shots.

Footage of a number of campus buildings including Chemistry, Food Service, University Press, Dental School, Student Publications, Angell Hall, President's House, Newberry House, TV Center, Botanical Gardens, Observatory, East Eng., and Hockey Rink.
Footage of a performance of the UM Symphony Band in Hill Auditorium, also footage of a high school graduation in Johanesburg, Michigan.
Footage of graduation ceremonies in Michigan Stadium, professors and students in academic robes, and shots of the crowd.
Footage of graduation ceremony including speakers, Navy ROTC cadets marching, and students and professors in academic robes.
Footage of floats, the parade, and crowd at the annual Michigras celebration.
Footage filmed for Engineering Centennial film includes shots of speakers at centennial ceremonies, students and professors, and old cars.
Footage of commencement exercises.
Footage of the Student Publications Building and equipment shows linotype machine and student paper coming off the press.
Footage of students in the East Quad cafeteria, girl writing letter in dorm room, and girls at Martha Cook dormitory having dinner with a professor.
Footage shot for film on the Locks includes shot of an Indian and trapper canoeing on waterway, and scenic shots of lake and river rapids.
Footage taken at Michigan stadium includes shots of ROTC cadets raising flag, the press booths, stadium pennants waving against the sky, and coaches on the sidelines.
Footage for a film on industrial exhaust systems includes shots of students and professors working in the UM fluid test laboratory and the engineering drawing lab.
Exterior shots of West Quad, the marquee of the Michigan theater, Pretzel Bell lights, interior shots of Michigan League, student working in geology lab, Ann Arbor train station, and the UM airport.
Shots of campus in the fall including students listening to speech on Diag, the Arboretum, Burton Tower, Law School, and students walking across campus or sitting on benches.

Footage taken at Stockwell women's dorm includes scenes of a student unloading car and moving in, interior of a dorm room. Also footage of the UM International Center and professor speaking with foreign students.
Footage of West Engineering Building and Engineering Arch and of street scenes along South University Ave.

Footage of a foundry, including a Bessemer Converter furnace, and various metal working labs. (UM?) Shots of men working lathes, a welding class, and men operating machine tools. Also shot of the inferior of the wind tunnel.
Shots of a variety of signs from campus and town including those for Adams House, Michigan Theater, Metzger's, Pretzel Bell, Sugar Bowl caf, and Slater's.
Shots of swimmers, divers, and spectators at a UM swimming and diving meet.
Art students in figure drawing class drawing nudes.
Footage of Ford Lemmler and other AVEC staff doing sound checks.
Footage of the AVEC production staff performing equipment checks.

Footage of campus buildings including Phoenix Lab, Television Center, Angell Hall addition, Women's Phys-Ed, Athletic Admin., Kresge Med., Cooley Lab, School of Public Health, Northwood Apts., Varsity Pool construction, Children's Psych. Hosp.

Michigan Stadium old press box, Yost Monument, U Hospital, Alice Lloyd Hall, Veterans' Readjustment Center, U. Terrace Apts., Ferry Field, Law Library, Outpatient Clinic, and School of Business Administration.
Footage of AVEC facilities and staff includes shots of the production unit in action, staff members using various pieces of equipment, the film library, and the repair room.
Footage of campus during winter includes shots of Romance Languages Building, Law School, Hill Aud., Engineering Arch, Clements Library and Martha Cook dormitory.

Footage of UM Marching Band performing in Michigan Stadium, high angle shots.

Footage shot in several UM medical clinics includes scenes of a woman working with a microscope, a girl receiving an injection, a male student taking water therapy, and a mass injection for students as they file through a room.

Footage taken in several UM medical clinics for film "Health is a Circle" includes shots of a girl receiving a complexion examination, electrocardiograph and blood pressure tests, and doctor examining student.
Footage shot in several UM medical clinics for film "Health Is a Circle" includes shots of nurse technician taking X-rays and doctor reading X-rays.

Footage of the UM Health Service for film "Health is a Circle" includes shots of the Health Service reception area, students being interviewed and the director of the Health service. Features: Morley Beckett, UM-Health Services
Footage of coeds sunbathing on the roof of Newberry House and at Palmer Field.
Footage of professors in academic gowns, ROTC unit marching and raising flag, and awarding of honorary degree to Secretary of Defense Charles Wilson.
Footage of Bert Lavastida of the AVEC and another man sitting in chairs talking.

Footage form the College of Engineering Centennial celebration included shots of the engineering centennial float at Engineering Arch, Air Force cadets marching, East Engineering entrance, professors and students.

Footage includes shots of Martha Cook hall with fruit tree in bloom, Dental School, Michigan Union and fountain, Burton Tower, Rackham Building, Frieze Building extension under construction, and students on the Diag.

Footage of high school marching bands performing at Michigan Stadium during UM Band Day.
Footage of high school marching bands performing at Michigan Stadium during UM Band Day.
Footage of high school marching bands performing at Michigan Stadium during UM Band Day.
Footage of students studying in the undergrad library, shot of library checkout desk and a microfilm reader.
Footage of students walking across the Diag, also a view of the Rackham Building from the Diag and a shot of the entrance to the Student Publications Office.
Footage of homecoming displays in front of fraternity and sorority houses.

Miscellaneous shots of campus activities, laboratories, classrooms, hospitals and clinics, includes clips from a number of AVEC productions, apparently compiled for the film "More Than Meets the Eye."
Miscellaneous footage of campus apparently taken for the film "More Than Meets the Eye" includes shots of classrooms, laboratories, and some social activities.
Footage of students and professors in a law school seminar.

did.abstract: Coverage of basketball game at Yost Field House with shot of Coach Strack on his birthday. Features: Dave Strack, UM-Ath.

did.abstract: Views of construction of Oxford Housing Project and Buhl Genetics Building, Spring, 1963, each more than half completed. Also unidentified footage - fraternity or sorority houses?

President Hatcher's speech dedicating the building. Dean Hubbard is Master of Ceremonies, Dean Furstenberg receives a portrait and speaks. Some shots of exterior of building. (Six reels and two magnetic sound tracks)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; Mrs. Harlan Hatcher; William Hubbard, UM-Med.; Albert Furstenberg, UM-Med.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, neg; wp; pos, b/w; b/w; b/w, sil; sil; sof, 1500 ft. total.

did.abstract: Samuel T. Dana, Dean Emeritus, School of Natural Resources introduces film, animated section illustrates establishment of UM and the changes in relationship with Mich. government which occurred in 1850. (Footage shot for film "Idea of Michigan.)"Features: Samuel T. Dana, UM-SNR; Wilma Donahue, UM-Geront.; Jonas Salk

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; pos, col; col, sof; sof, 490; 700

did.abstract: Misc. coverage of campus, classrooms, students. Outstate coverage of UM-Flint, Clinton River, Mackinac Bridge, UM-Dearborn, Biological Station in Northern Michigan, Milan, Mich. (Footage shot for film "Idea of Michigan.")

did.unittitle: Ray W. Herrick, Tecumseh Products, Receiving Award 1963
did.abstract: Presentation of Regents Citation of Honor to Mr. Ray W. Herrick, head of Tecumseh Products, Apr. 18, 1963. Mr. Herrick is honored at a luncheon at the Union, at a ceremony in Clements Library. Many regents & VIP's in footage. (Total of seven reels.)Features: Ray W. Herrick, Tecumseh Products

did.unittitle: Spring Weekend, Contests and Costume Events 1963
did.abstract: Activities of Spring Weekend, contests and costumes events, footage of Dr. Hazel Losh judging canoe event at Island Park on Huron River, Parade, helicopter landing and takeoff. (Film spliced and out of order.)Features: Hazel Losh, UM-Astron.

did.unittitle: Men's Glee Club Return from Europe, Summer, 1963 1963
did.abstract: Men's Glee Club is filmed upon their return from Europe at Willow Run Airport. Crowd shots include Philip Duey, Conductor, WUOM's Fred Hindley, and the Secretary of the University. Features: Philip Duey, UM-Music ; Fred Hindley, UM-WUOM

Footage of a portion of commencement speech by C.P. Snow. General coverage of arrival of VIP's, honorary degree awards, also a press conference held by Snow in Regents' Room. (Total of six reels) Features: C.P. Snow, Rev. John Burgess, Alden Dow, Nathan Eddy, John Gordon, Roman Jacobson, Emory Morris, Judge Tavares

Press conference held by Snow in Regents' Room. (Following graduation ceremony?)Features: C.P. Snow, Rev. John Burgess, Alden Dow, Nathan Eddy, John Gordon, Roman Jacobson, Emory Morris, Judge Tavares

did.abstract: Work print of rolls A and B? Features: C.P. Snow, Rev. John Burgess, Alden Dow, Nathan Eddy, John Gordon, Roman Jacobson, Emory Morris, Judge Tavares

Miscellaneous footage of pre and post ceremony and some shots of honorary degree, (ground camera?)Features: C.P. Snow, Rev. John Burgess, Alden Dow, Nathan Eddy, John Gordon, Roman Jacobson, Emory Morris, Judge Tavares

did.unittitle: UM Alumni Camp, Boyne City, August, 1963 1963
did.abstract: General coverage of activity at the Alumni Camp, shots of water front, picnic. Bill Stegeth, camp director, describing Camp, square dancing, Dean Robertson lecturing. (Sound on col. pos. is not good.)Features: Bill Stegeth, UM-Camp Michigania ; James Robertson, UM-LSA

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil; sot, 700;

did.abstract: Footage of varied activities at science and technology fair at North Campus and Main Campus, crowds of UM students and children viewing scientific exhibits.

U.S. Secretary of Labor, W. Willard Wirtz, is commencement speaker. Footage of Sec. Wirtz and Pres. Hatcher conversing in Regents' Room prior to commencement. Footage of press conference held by Sec. Wirtz on same day. Features: W. Willard Wirtz, U.S. Secretary of Labor ; Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.

President Hatcher discusses many current UM problems, including the undergraduate program. Filmed on 12/13/63. Questions are read by Hazen Schumacher. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Hazen Schumacher, UM-TVC

Mr. Dey is given an Honorary Degree in special ceremonies. Footage of Mr. Dey during casual sightseeing, at Union and on State St., Mr. Dey is shown with Pres. Hatcher in front of the Rackham Bldg. just before ceremony. Features: Subendra Kumar Dey ; Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.

did.unittitle: Lynn Townsend Receiving Business Leadership Award 1963
did.abstract: Two UM Bus. Ad. students present Mr. Lynn A. Townsend, Pres. of Chrysler Corp. with the 1963 Business Leadership Award from the UM Graduate School of Business Administration. Features: Lynn Townsend

did.abstract: Various shots of Tuskegee Institute Choir. Features: Tuskegee Institute Choir

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; wp, col; col; col, sil; sil; sil; sot, 300; 300

did.abstract: Coverage of UM Marching Band performance, pre-game shots, Hawaiian War Chant marching formation. (Total of four reels plus cutaways.)Features: Marching Band

did.abstract: Coverage of pre-game band performance and crowd shots. Features: George Romney, Lenore Romney, UM Marching Band
Footage of greeting of sorority guests, various shots of guests in sorority house. (Some of this footage has also been spliced into Archives #122.)Features: UM Sorority

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; wp, col; col; col, sil; sil; sil, ; 280; 280

did.abstract: Miscellaneous shots around Main Campus during Registration Week, Fall, 1963.

did.unittitle: Navy-Michigan Football Game, Fall, 1963 and WVGR 1963
did.abstract: Stadium and Campus shots. (Some snow scenes spliced in.) UM Marching Band, UM Stadium, football crowd, cheerleaders, UM Grand Rapids radio station WVGR, Middleville Village Sign. Features: Marching Band

did.unittitle: Navy-Michigan Football Game, Fall, 1963 and WVGR 1963
did.abstract: Miscellaneous shots as follows: Navy/UM Football - mostly crowd shots, WVGR UM Radio in Grand Rapids, Engr. Dick Clarke at controls, Tom Montgomery at racks, WVGR sign on building and the station tower. Features: Dick Clarke, Engr. WVGR ; Tom Montgomery, Engr. WVGR

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; pos; wp, col; col; col; b/w, sil; sil; sil; sil

did.unittitle: Stewart Udall, U.S. Secretary of the Interior
did.abstract: Footage of Secretary Udall at the UM television studio, being made up for his appearance on the UM television series "Understanding Our World". (see series B "Secretary of the Interior: Stewart Udall")Features: Stewart Udall, U.S. Secretary of the Interior

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; neg, b/w; b/w, sil; sil, 100; 100

did.abstract: Professor is shown instructing students on basic atomic structure - protons, electrons.

Filmed are the Mideast Basketball Championships held in Milwaukee. U-M basketball team winning against Loyola, Ohio University also plays at the Championships. (Film #121 on reel with #122, also on reel with #s114, 121,122,125-128.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; pos; wp, col; b/w; b/w, sil; sil; sil, 200; 200; 200

did.unittitle: Snowstorm in Ann Arbor: Campus in Seasons 1964
did.abstract: Various shots around Main Campus of students struggling (happily) through heavy snows. Old Observatory Building is shown. (Some footage of Archives #116 spliced in on one reel.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; wp, col; col; col, sil; sil; sil

did.abstract: Gymnastics practice. Newt Locken (Coach) with team practicing various gymnastics events. Features: Newt Locken, UM-Ath.

did.abstract: Footage of a UM gymnastics meet and of a UM hockey game at Yost arena.
Footage of UM hockey team practicing in Yost Arena.
Brief footage of a UM wrestler in a wrestling match.
Swimming practice. Includes shots of Coach Stager. Features: Gus Stager, UM-Ath.
Footage of a swimming meet between Michigan and Indiana.
Footage of basketball team warming-up at practice. (Footage is dark.)
Footage from Michigan basketball victory over Illinois.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; b/w, sil; sil, 200

did.abstract: Brief footage of Michigan's loss to Duke in the NCAA semi-final basketball game held in Kansas City, one shot of team coming out of dressing room.

Donald C. Cook is presented 1963 Business Leadership Award, April, 1964. Mr. Cook is president of American Electric Power Co. and former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Features: Donald C. Cook, Pres. American Electric Power Co.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, b/w; col, sil; sof; sot; at, 100; 100; 100

did.abstract: President Hatcher and other dignitaries make several speeches at ceremonies marking Founders Day at Tuskegee Institute. Footage of Tuskegee campus, nursing students, ROTC, and a campus parade. (On core with Archives #135-137.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.

did.unittitle: Richard Wilson Lecturing to Engineering Class 1964
did.abstract: Dr. Wilson, 1964 Faculty Award Winner, is filmed lecturing to engineering class at Flint Extension. (On core with Archives 135-137.)Features: Richard Wilson, UM-Eng.
Spring rainstorm on Campus. Various shots of students with umbrellas, jumping over puddles, etc. (On core with Archives #134-137.)

did.unittitle: Michigras Parade and Dance Contest, Spring 1964
did.abstract: Michigras parade and frug dance contest, Pres. and Mrs. Hatcher and Sonny Elliott are in parade, also parade shots of floats, bands, crowd, and the dance contest on the mall. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Mrs. Harlan Hatcher ; Sonny Elliott, TV Weathercaster, Bunny (from Detroit Playboy Club?)

did.unittitle: Richard Wilson Lecturing to Engineering Class 1964
did.abstract: Richard Wilson, Faculty Award Winner, lectures to his engineering class on campus in Ann Arbor. (On core with Archives 134-137.)Features: Richard Wilson, UM-Eng.

did.unittitle: D. Dumond & J. Griffin Discussing Civil Rights 1964
did.abstract: Faculty Award Winner, Dwight Dumond talks about the FBI civil rights investigation. John Griffin, author of "Black Like Me," talks about civil rights. (Some imperfection in film but footage is usable.) Features: Dwight Dumond, UM-Hist. ; John Griffin, author

David Dennison, Chairman of Physics Department and 1964 Faculty Award Winner, discusses his career at UM, problems and solutions in running the Physics Department. (Needs repair.)Features: David Dennison, UM-Physics

did.unittitle: Kennedy Peace Corps Plaque at Union Dedication 1964
did.abstract: President Hatcher and dignitaries are shown on platform in front of Michigan Union. Film consists mostly of crowd shots, a solemn crowd gathered in front of the Union. (Also includes misc. shots of old School of Music and students on the Diag.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Harlan Cleveland.
Exterior shot of door and wall of building with bike rack near the door. Students shown arriving on bikes, parking, and entering door. Also students shown on the Diag in Spring.

did.unittitle: Music School Move to North Campus, May, 1964 1964
did.abstract: Shots of moving vans at Lane Hall, Burton Tower, and Maynard St. School of Music Building.
Footage of Music School's move, one of the organs in the Maynard St. School of Music is dismantled prior to being moved to the new building on North Campus.
Sorority members filmed in their living room exchanging gifts. Pan-Hellenic president Ann Wickens is present. Features: Ann Wickens, Pan-Hellenic Pres. ; Sigma Kappa Sorority

did.unittitle: Michigan Band at World's Fair & Rockefeller Centre 1964
did.abstract: Michigan Concert band plays at GM Display and at American Pavilion. Shots of Prof. Revelli, Gov. Romney, Gov. Rockefeller. Next day concert at Rockefeller Centre is also filmed. (Total of six reels)Features: William D. Revelli ; UM-Music ; George Romney ; Nelson Rockefeller

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil, 400; 400

did.abstract: A work print copy of film with sound of a portion of President Johnson's "Great Society" speech.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; wp, col; col, sil; sil; sot, 100

scopecontent.p: Original camera footage (6 reels) and separate magnetic sound track (2 reels) recorded from WUOM radio feed of the ceremony and speech. The audio captures the entire ceremony and Johnsons speech. The film, shot with two cameras, does nor record the entire ceremony or speech. None of the original film reels have been synched with the audio. Film shows all honorary degree recipients;. extensive cutaways before, during, and after the graduation ceremonies, many crowd shots; Pres. Johnson shown landing and departing by Marine helicopter, entering and leaving the stadium. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; G. Mennen Williams, George Romney, Merle Curti, John C. Bugher, Clarence L. Johnson, Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson

did.abstract: Portions of Johnson's Speech Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; G. Mennen Williams, George Romney, Merle Curti, John C. Bugher, Clarence L. Johnson, Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson

1964 Commencement, Pres. Lyndon Johnson speaker. [Stage Camera] Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; G. Mennen Williams, George Romney, Merle Curti, John C. Bugher, Clarence L. Johnson, Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson
1964 Commencement, Pres. Lyndon Johnson speaker. [Platform camera,]

1964 Commencement, Pres. Lyndon Johnson speaker. ["Alley's Work Print"} Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; G. Mennen Williams, George Romney, Merle Curti, John C. Bugher, Clarence L. Johnson, Pres. Lyndon B. Johnson
1964 Commencement, Pres. Lyndon Johnson speaker. [AB 3000 original color]
1964 Commencement, Pres. Lyndon Johnson speaker. [AB 4000 original color]

Sophomore Basketball star Russell talks (in front of the Physics and Astronomy Bldg.) about his experiences as an athlete and as a Negro. (Several takes, some without sound.) Features: Cazzie Russell, UM Basketball Star

did.unittitle: Ralph Sawyer, Retiring VP for Research, Interview 1964
did.abstract: Vice Pres. Ralph A. Sawyer discusses UM research activities as they evolved and grew in scope during his years as VP for Research. VP Sawyer stands atop the VA Hosp. Excellent panoramic views of North Campus. Features: Ralph A. Sawyer, UM-VP

did.unittitle: Fritz Crisler, Director of Athletics, Spring, 1964 1964
did.abstract: Filmed in empty UM stadium. Mr. Crisler recollects many experiences and talks about a wide range of topics on the 25th anniversary of his association with UM. Features: Fritz Crisler, UM-Ath.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col, sof; sil, at, 200

did.unittitle: Ralph A. Sawyer, Retiring VP for Research 1964
did.abstract: Ralph A. Sawyer, former Dean of the Rackham School of Graduate Studies, discusses changes in the Graduate School over the years, and his long career at UM. Features: Ralph A. Sawyer, UM-VP
Shots of various buildings on Tuskegee campus, students, exterior shot of George Washington Carver Museum and bust of George Washington Carver.
Editor of the Michigan Daily talks about his views of UM campus mostly about size problems and solutions. (Needs repair.)

did.unittitle: Harlan Lane describing the SAID System 1964
did.abstract: Psychology Prof. Harlan Lane, a Distinguished Faculty Award Winner, describes research project SAID, a computer system used to teach foreign languages. Extensive footage of the SAID system in operation. Features: Harlan Lane, UM-Psych.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, col; col, sof; sof; sot, 1100; 1100

did.abstract: The new Genetics Lab on Catherine St. is dedicated, Spring, 1964. Many UM VIP's including VP Sawyer, Pres. Hatcher, Dr. Neel. Ceremony takes place outside on lawn. (On core with #155-157.)Features: Ralph A. Sawyer, UM-VP ; Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; James V. Neel, UM-Genetics

Footage of fuel loading at Phoenix nuclear reactor on North Campus, old fuel being removed and being lifted into special truck, interior shots of fuel being handled with mechanical arms. (On core with 154-157) (Needs repair.)

did.unittitle: Dr. Luther Foster, Pres., Tuskegee Institute 1964
did.abstract: Dr. Foster discusses aspects of Tuskegee Institute - University of Michigan cooperative programs, Summer, 1964. (On core with 154-157.)Features: Luther Foster, Pres. Tuskegee Institute

did.unittitle: Norman Miller, Head of Women's Hospital, Interview 1964
did.abstract: Norman Miller, head of the UM Women's Hospital and Faculty Award Winner, talks about his hobbies, views on change in the UM Medical School over the years. (On core with 154-157.)Features: Norman Miller, UM-Med.

did.unittitle: William Fry Teaching at University Hospital 1964
did.abstract: William Fry, Distinguished Faculty Award Winner, Summer, 1964, teaching in a classroom at UM Hospital. Features: William Fry, UM-Med.

did.unittitle: Campus views and anthropological dig, Grand Rapids 1964
did.abstract: Various Campus shots: Law School, Pres. Kennedy Peace Corps Plaque, UM stadium, empty. General coverage of a dig by Anthropology Dept. of Hopewell Culture American Indian Mounds near Grand Rapids. (Footage used in TV program "Hopewell Heritage.")Features: James Griffin, UM-Anthro.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; pos, col; col; col, sil; sil; sil, 200; 200; 200

did.unittitle: Campus Shots - Angell Hall, Music School, Students circa 1964
did.abstract: Various shots around campus. Excellent footage of Angell Hall. Shots of students studying on Diag and lawn. Poor quality footage of the Music School. (On core with #161.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; , col; col, sil; sil, 200; 200

did.abstract: Various shots of the interior of the new Music School Building including the library and Professor Brossart's piano studio and the band music sorting racks. Features: R. Eugene Brossart, UM-Music

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil,sil, 300; 300

did.unittitle: Students Looking at Peace Corps Plaque 1964
did.abstract: UM students looking at plaque on Michigan Union commemorating President Kennedy's announcement of the Peace Corps. Good close-up of the plaque.
Footage from the UM camp for delinquent boys includes shots of boys and counselors at various camp activities.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil, 200; 200

did.abstract: Footage from the UM rocket launch site shows rocket launcher, data recording equipment, launch crew and VIP observers, loading of the rocket, and a rocket launch.

Footage of the dedication ceremony at new Music Building includes presentation of awards to Eileen Saarinen, Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copeland and others, some footage of Bernstein and Copeland conducting UM orchestra, views of building and grounds. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Eileen Saarinen, Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copeland, Charles Sink

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil; at, 100; 100

did.abstract: Cutaways of crowd and players at UM-Purdue football game. Good footage of UM Marching band in formation, Victor Borge hamming it up in the press box. (On core with #168,170)Features: Marching Band ; Victor Borge

Presentation of Faculty Awards, includes footage of Pres. Hatcher speaking and the award ceremony. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; Reed Nesbit, UM-Med.; Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.; Norman Thomas, UM-Pol.; Kenneth Boulding, UM-Econ; Caesar Blake, UM-Engl.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, col; col, sof; sof; at, 500; 545

did.unittitle: Sargent Shriver, Director of the Peace Corps 1964
did.abstract: Shriver talks to a large crowd of students outside Michigan Union at the site of a plaque commemorating President Kennedy's announcement of the Peace Corps. (On core with #166, 170.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Sargent Shriver

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; wp, col; col, sil; sil; at, 98, 98

did.abstract: Footage of recipients of honorary degrees at ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of instruction in aeronautical engineering at the University of Michigan. Honorees are UM alums who distinguished themselves in aeronautical or aerospace engineering. Features: William Hawkins ; Allen Donovan ; James Dempsey
Pickets and rally protesting appearance of American Nazi Party leader George Lincoln Rockwell at Hill Auditorium. Filmed at night outside Hill Auditorium. (On core with #166, 168.)
Footage of Homecoming activities including the "mudbowl," a tug-of-war across the Huron River, fraternity and sorority displays and sculptures, and a soap-box derby. (On reel with #173.)

Rally on the Diag before the football team left for Columbus to play Ohio State, including shots of President Hatcher and Coach Elliot. Also footage of the arrival of the victorious team at Willow Run airport. (On reel with #171)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Charles "Bump" Elliot, UM-Ath.
Footage taken during and after a severe snowstorm. Campus scenes of snow removal, cars on unplowed streets, students walking through snow to Angell Hall. (120 foot version is on core with #186-189.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, col; col, sil; sil, 80; 120

did.abstract: Footage of an alumni awards luncheon includes the Emeritus Club awards ceremony, the luncheon, a meeting of Medical Alumni, and several alumni from the class of 1911. (Total of 3 negative and 3 work prints.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Edward R. Murrow

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, neg; wp, b/w; b/w, sil; sil, 1000; 1000

did.abstract: Footage of the signing of an agreement between the University of Michigan and the United States Public Health Service to build a Water Pollution Laboratory. (Copyright held by USPHS.)

Complete footage of the Michigan's 21-0 football victory over the Naval Academy and most of the half-time band show. (Three reels of film, two of game and one of band show and cutaways. Two reels of magnetic sound track, 6 reels audio tape.)Features: Marching Band

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos; pos, col; col; col, sof; sof; sof; sot, 2000

did.unittitle: Institute of Science and Technology Dedication 1964
did.abstract: Footage from the open house during the dedication of the IST building on North Campus, includes good shots of equipment, displays and laboratories.
Good footage of the exterior of the new Music School building and the reflecting pond.

did.unittitle: Campus Scenes from "Idea of Michigan" Trims 1960
did.abstract: Footage shot for the film "Idea of Michigan." Includes shots of Burton Tower, Rackham Building, Health Services, women's dormitories, Frieze Building, Phoenix Memorial Lab, and the President's House. (On core with #182.)

Film of press conference in Rackham Auditorium prior to announcing successful test of the Salk polio vaccine. Dr Francis and Dr. Salk talk about the development of the vaccine and testing methods. Features: Thomas Francis Jr., UM-SPH ; Jonas Salk, E. Van Ryper, David Bodian, Thomas Rivers, Basil O'Connor

Footage of a Great Lakes Research Institute research vessel taking core samples from bottom of one of the Great Lakes. Close-ups of men working the drilling equipment on board ship. (On core with #180.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, col; col, sil; sil, 200; 200

did.abstract: Footage of commencement speaker Thurgood Marshall in conversation with unidentified man and of President Hatcher in informal discussions. (On core with #185, film has a blue tint.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Thurgood Marshall

Footage of the Michigan - Ohio State basketball game, cutaways of the band performing, and of the presentation of the football player of the year award to Bob Timberlake. Features: Bob Timberlake, Football Player of The Year

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil, 300; 300

did.abstract: Several shots of plaque by front door of Michigan League--commemorates anniversary of the building. Women posing by plaque are not identified, except blonde girl is Nancy Freitag, League Pres., 1964-65. Features: Nancy Freitag, League Pres., 1964-65
Footage of a civil rights march and rally on the UM campus and in downtown Ann Arbor, apparently in support of civil rights activities in Selma, Alabama. (One copy on core with #187-189.)
Film clips from Michigan's 88-85 basketball win over Minnesota. (On cores with #184 and #186-189.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, col; col, sil; sil, 340; 340

did.abstract: Footage of Marina Oswald, widow of Kennedy assassin Lee Harvey Oswald, receiving diploma from the director of the English Language Institute. (One on core with #186-189.) (Needs repair.)Features: Marina Oswald ; John Catford, UM-ELI

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; wp, col; col, sil; sil

did.abstract: Footage of UM wrestling match, shots of wrestling coach Cliff Keen. Filmed at Yost Field House. Features: Clifford Keen, UM-Wrestling Coach

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos.wp, col; col, sil; sil, 135; 135

did.abstract: Coverage of crowds and speakers on the Diag and first Vietnam War Teach-In held in Mason Hall at the University of Michigan, interviews Eric Wolfe and William Gamson, two of the organizers (Dupe neg. from B wind reversal shot by WXYZ, Ch. 7 Detroit.)Features: William Gamson, UM-Soc.; Eric Wolfe, UM-Anthro.; Bill Bonds, Ch 7 TV Newscaster
Shots of crowd in Haven Hall Lobby (Fishbowl) and in lecture hall, crowd and speakers
On-campus shots of female legs showing many different stocking and boot styles.

Exterior views of robed dignitaries leaving President's House, getting into limos. Also shots of Pres. Hatcher and guests inside President's House. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands ; George Romney
James Reston and reporters in Regents' Room in the Administration Bldg. Features: James Reston, NY Times

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, neg; wp, b/w; b/w, sil; sil; at, 200; 200

did.abstract: Footage of Michigan's win over Vanderbilt in NCAA basketball regional final at Lexington, Ky., 1965. (Three reels of audiotape of the basketball game.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, b/w; col; col, b/w; col; col, sil; sil; sil; at, 100; 100; 100

did.abstract: Footage of the Medical School graduation and the Hippocratic oath ceremony.

Long and close-up shots of 3 UM boats, all taken in 1 day on Lake Mich. and in Grand Haven Harbor. Shots of men working with equipment, dredge, sample bottles, interior shots of boat, underwater TV (?) Boats are Inland Seas, Mysis, Highland Lassie.

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; wp, col; col, sil; sil, 1060

did.abstract: Presentation of honorary degrees at 1965 graduation ceremony. (2 reels of audiotape, sof is of poor quality.)Features: Harlan Hatcher-UM Pres., James Reston, NY Times

did.abstract: Astronauts filmed at the Airport, UM Stadium. Also footage of the Dedication of the UM Space Research Laboratory. (There are four reels of magnetic sound track and 3 reels of audiotape to accompany this title.)Features: Pres. & Mrs. Hatcher, Governor and Lenore Romney, James McDivitt and spouse, Edward White and spouse.
Footage of Edward White's Address given at the Honorary Degree Awards in UM Stadium. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Edward White, Astronaut ; James McDivitt, Astronaut.
Astronauts being greeted at Airport, reception line. (NASA plane.)Features: Pres. & Mrs. Hatcher ; Gov. and Lenore Romney ; James McDivitt and spouse, Edward White and spouse
Astronauts at commencement, presentation of Honorary Degrees at UM Stadium
Dedication of Aerospace Engineering Building, North Campus. Features: James McDivitt, Astronaut ; Edward White, Astronaut, Dr. Thompson, NASA; Dr. Webb, NASA
Footage of Astronaut Edward White speaking at commencement in UM Stadium, talks of his UM background and the quality of his education at Michigan. Features: Edward White, Astronaut

Lt. Col. James McDivitt and Col. Edward White (Gemini IV) are filmed receiving honorary degrees, both address graduates, Ann Arbor High School Band plays. Features: James McDivitt, Astronaut ; Edward White, Astronaut ; Ann Arbor High School Band

Presentation of clocks to astronauts White and McDivitt, also a resolution of the state of Michigan honoring their achievement, presentation of honorary degrees. did.abstract: Footage of UM-MSU baseball game, good shots of team in the dugout and of a sparse crowd.

Film of the Starr II research mini-submarine used by the UM Great Lakes Research Institute. Footage includes close-ups of the sub on deck of a UM research vessel, shots of sub being lowered into water and lifted onto ship. (Needs repair.)
Various shots of Native Americans in traditional garb, performing a series of dances in front of the Music School Pond. Shots of crowd sitting on grass.
Series of shots of Art Fair. Good inside shot of Nichols Arcade, shots of displays and crowds.

Erhardt (West Germany) at press conference, seated at table with 2 others, one (woman) is interpreter or spokesperson. Erhardt speaks very briefly. (Sound on color print is very garbled.)Features: Erhardt (West Germany)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, pos; pos, b/w; col, sil; sof, 160; 225

did.abstract: Footage of participants in the 23rd International Congress of Orientalists Hosted by UM as part of Sesquicentennial observance, includes arrival at airport, various conference activities, address by Gov. Romney, tour of Greenfield Village. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; George Romney

Part 1.; Film from the Michigan Union opera company's tour in Korea includes, on-stage performances and visits to hospitals in Seoul and at Kimpo Air Base, also shots of the group traveling. The tour was part of the UM Sesquicentennial observance. Features: UM Muskets

Part 2.; Footage from the MUSKET tour of Japan includes shots of the group performing on-stage, in a hospital and on board the USS Constellation. Also footage of a hurricane. (Needs repair.)Features: UM Muskets
Part 3.; Footage of MUSKET's arrival at Metro Airport from tour of Korea and Japan. Some of this film is from Channel 7 News. (Needs repair, spliced out of order and upside down.)Features: UM Muskets
Part 4.; Film of MUSKET leaving for tour of the Far East to entertain the troops. Also additional footage of the group's return at Metropolitan Airport. Features: UM Muskets
Exhibit of Tao Chiev is shown. Man is shown looking at various art works, hanging a scroll and reading it. Features: Tao Chiev

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; pos, b/w; col, sil; sil, 80; 100

did.abstract: Interview with conductor Leonard Bernstein sitting at the piano, smoking as he talks. Close-up and cutaway shots of both Mr. Bernstein and interviewer. Features: Leonard Bernstein

(Needs repair, sot is Acheson)Features: Robben Fleming, UM-Pres. ; Dean Acheson ; Urey Chandraseka

did.abstract: Dean Acheson at breakfast., many good candid shots of Acheson talking with various people at breakfast, seated on fireplace hearth talking informally with students. Features: Dean Acheson
Footage of Gunnar Myrdal and Ralph Ellison with debate moderator before debate and brief footage of the debate. Filmed in Hill Auditorium. Features: Gunnar Myrdal ; Ralph Ellison

Hamada Interview.; Leading Japanese folk potter and director of the national museum is interviewed, film clip show Hamada in native dress, throwing pots on a wheel. He was on campus as part of UM Sesquicentennial observance. (See Series A #200)Features: John Stephenson, UM-Art ; Hamada

did.abstract: Father Hickey addressing group of about 25 people. Photograph of a book is shown. Features: Father Hickey
Mr. Rockefeller speaks directly into camera. He later speaks with members of the group. Features: J.D. Rockefeller
Footage of UM-Kentucky basketball game, inaugural game at the Events Center, Pres. Hatcher throws out the first ball. (film is dark.)Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.

Footage of a banquet in Crisler Arena marking the success of the UM $55 million capital campaign, includes shots of the dinner and several speakers and brief footage of Presidents Hatcher, Fleming, and Ruthven together. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres. ; Robben Fleming, UM-Pres. ; Alexander Ruthven, UM-Pres.
Footage of UM's 27-7 victory over Wisconsin in Madison.
President Fleming makes a statement and then answers questions at press conference. Features: Robben Fleming, UM-Pres.

did.abstract: Footage of UM Psychology professor Floyd Mann being interviewed. Features: Floyd Mann, UM-Psych.

Part I.; Documentary footage of Chemistry Dept. faculty in their classrooms, office or laboratories. Over 40 individuals are filmed, each accompanied by an identifying target giving name, educational background, and years at UM. Features: Charles G. Overberger, UM-Chem. ; Robert C. Taylor, UM-Chem. ; Leigh C. Anderson, UM-Chem.

Part II.; Films of Chemistry Dept. faculty, 1936-1943, edited and titled in 1967. Films were shot in classrooms, offices, or laboratories. Ca. 30 individuals filmed, each accompanied by identifying target giving name, education, and years at UM. Features: Moses Gomberg, UM-Chem. ; Chester S. Schoepfle, UM-Chem., et al.
Series of shots of Michigan Daily newspaper headlines. Topics include Fall tuition hike, new president selection, classified research, Middle East Crisis, and Cinema Guild.

Film of Dr. Barnard's press conference. He is seated at a table with Donald Kahn, UM-Med. and Fred Hindley of WUOM. (See Series B #644.)(Total of five reels film and 1 audiotape.)Features: Dr. Christiaan Barnard ; Donald Kahn, UM-Med. ; Fred Hindley, UM-WUOM.

Footage of people entering and leaving the Michigan League for performance by MUSKET.
Series of exterior shots of the University Events Building, grounds are not yet landscaped.

Film of Fleming's inaugural address, shots of participants on platform, outdoor shots of academic procession leaving Rackham, excellent shot of President Fleming in presidential robes. Features: Robben Fleming, UM-Pres.

Tourism film from Michigan Tourist Council, includes footage of various scenic spots in the state, some good shots of Mackinac Bridge and a close-up of the Michigan state seal.
Brief footage of dinner meeting of the UM Quarterback Club in Crisler Arena. Informal shots of three winners of awards. Features: Don Canham, UM-Ath.
Film begins with shots of a tennis match, then various shots of the UM Central Michigan baseball. (Parts of film overexposed.)

Hay, UM-Ass't Dean Rackham; Norma Scott, UM-Dean Dearborn Campus
Various shots of "Bo" in his new office (shown with two unidentified men). Features: Bo Schembechler, UM-Ath.

Brief footage of Robert Hayden and a woman leafing through a book, and a shot of a Hopwood Awards poster. Features: Robert Hayden, UM-Engl.

Footage of East Quad, Economics Building, shot filmed through Engineering Arch across the Diag.

Outside shots of UM students working with children at the Merrill-Palmer Institute in Detroit, shows children modeling clay, playing on playground equipment. (Some of the following "student relations" films done for Series F "Concerned Generation.")

James Shaw, Ass't Dean of LS& A, is filmed on steps of Angell Hall with small group of students picketing behind him. Dean Shaw speaks directly into camera, and one student speaks also. Features: James Shaw, UM-Ass't Dean LSA

did.unittitle: Student Relations, Interviews at Alice Lloyd Hall 1969
did.abstract: Footage of interviews with four residents of Alice Lloyd women's dormitory. Housemother / resident advisor is filmed in office, shot of bulletin board filled with messages, posters, protests.
Black female UM student is shown instructing a group of Black youths in what appears to be a church basement. (This footage used in Series F "Concerned Generation.")
Footage of UM faculty and students (SPH or SNR?) in pontoon boat on Crystal Lake taking water samples.

Film of students protesting ROTC on campus, students are gathering outside ROTC offices in North Hall, close-up shot of handout "In Case of Arrest," students are shown rushing into building attempting to take over ROTC office.

did.unittitle: Student Relations, Legal Aid Clinic, Crisis Center 1969
did.abstract: Footage of law student operated Legal Aid Clinic, shows clients being counseled, shot of Clinic sign on outside of building.
Protest Meeting(?) Footage of what appears to be a panel of administrators or faculty addressing a large group of students.
Random "60s" shots on Diag and South University Ave., a multicolored psychedelic van, South University street scenes showing "the heads."

Students at the Pretzel Bell, drinking beer, shows the Bell birthday tradition. Captures the ambiance of this favored gathering place. Footage at end of film of swimmers in an indoor pool. (Film is quite dark.)
Footage of students milling around in the student operated Counseling Office. Features: Al Slote, UM-TVC, Mike Shotka

Footage of activity on Diag. Random; Large number of students on Diag. Banner-Ramsay Clark. Sign "Smash Imperialism". shots of posters, leaflets being passed out, "heads" strumming guitars, NLF flag in background, an all green person playing guitar, "60s" dress and hair styles. Some footage of registration at Waterman Gymnasium.

Students at a local pub, musicians performing on stage. (Film very dark.)
Footage of students on Diag in summer, everyone in casual dress, bell bottoms, etc. Skirts are short, young faces, everybody busy, Diag is crowded.
Footage of history professor Louis Orlin talking to students, lecturing in classroom, interview with Al Slote, in office with student. (Needs repair.)Features: Louis Orlin, UM-Hist.; Al Slote, UM-TVC

Professor Ackley.; Footage of interview with UM economics professor and former White House advisor Gardner Ackley. Features: Gardner Ackley, UM-Econ.
Professor Shulman in lecture hall, at blackboard. Interesting, animated teaching style. Good shots of students. Features: Mary Shulman, UM-Econ.
Professor Matoon sitting in front of students. Some interesting shots of students taking notes. Small class (6-8). (Needs reaper.)Features: Lyn Mattoon, UM-Phil.

Footage of UM laboratory equipment used in testing design and impact resistance of football helmets includes shots of the sled and track used to simulate impact and a variety of measurement and date recording devices.
Additional footage of laboratory equipment used in testing design and impact resistance of football helmets.

did.unittitle: Dr. Les Soper, Monkey Hypothermia Experiment
did.abstract: Footage of laboratory experiment on effect of hypothermia on monkeys. Shots of Dr. Soper conducting psychological tests on monkey, performing surgery on monkey, and measuring impact of hypothermia on heart function and brain activity.

Footage of campaign and election of student government officers includes shots of banners on Diag, posters, candidates speaking, candidates in WCBN studio, students voting in the Fishbowl, ballot counting, and a victory celebration.
Film of a meeting, possibly Board of Regents and Ford Foundation officials, apparently regarding Ford Foundations contribution to the UM $55 million capital campaign.
Footage of floats and a few bands from the 1951 tournament of Roses Parade, including the University of Michigan float. This film was produced by Sportsreel Productions.
Footage of a UM student in a laboratory performing emissions test on a car.
A UM engineering professor demonstrates a model robot.
UM aeronautical engineering students are shown working on designs of a robot, professor demonstrates a model robot.

Footage of the Fleming family and friends at tea at the President's House, Fleming gives a tour of the house, inaugural banquet in Michigan Union(?), procession and ceremony in Hill Auditorium, Fleming's address. (Sound track for part of speech.)Features: Robben Fleming, UM-Pres.

Footage of UM Marching Band performing at half-time of Rose Bowl game.

Footage of the last quarter of the UM vs. Oregon State Rose Bowl game and post game activities, including Marching Band plying on field, tearing down of the goal posts, and fan's celebration.
Game footage of Michigan vs Oregon State Rose Bowl.
UM Marching band performance at half-time of Rose Bowl game. Features: Marching Band

did.abstract: Rose Bowl game footage including several Michigan scoring plays from the second-half and the final plays of the game, the UM Marching Band performing on the field after the game, and fans celebrating and tearing down the goalposts. Features: Marching Band

Film footage of photographs depicting natural resources, agricultural activities, industrial plants in Detroit, Grand Rapids and Battle Creek, and recreational and educational resources of Michigan. (Several takes, includes music but no narrative.)
UM doctor illustrates technique of molding an artificial ear which will be attached to a child suffering from an ear deformity.
UM researchers are shown preparing flu vaccine in a laboratory, injecting eggs with a virus.
Footage of the 1948 Tournament of Roses Parade including the UM Marching Band and the Michigan float. (Work print and original B-wind.)Features: Marching Band

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; pos, col; col, sil; sil, 120; 120

did.abstract: Camp Michigania.; Footage of facilities and activities at UM Alumni Association's Camp Michigania, including shots of archery range, lakefront and beach, sailboats, cabins and dining facilities, and a UM professor lecturing.

Continues footage of Camp Michigania activities including horseback riding and swimming. Also filmed footage of still photographs including a man jumping over the Diag "M", Vulcans at anvil, and Economics Building. (Filmed for "We Came to Ann Arbor")

Footage of a variety of campus and town scenes including "Shakey Jake" Woods playing guitar on the Diag, Ulrich's Bookstore, Overbeck's Bookstore, and campus buildings including Economics, LS&A, Kelsey, Engineering Arch, Hill Aud. and Dental School. Features: "Shakey Jake" Woods

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, wp; pos, col; col, sil; sil, 480; 480

did.abstract: Christmas party for child patients at University Hospital sponsored by the Galens Society. Also footage of what appears to be a computer screen in which a man uses light pen to give instructions for plotting regression analysis?
Footage of Galens Society members collecting donations on campus and downtown Ann Arbor.

Three to five minute tape of UM football game in which a fan raced out of the stands and attempted to tackle Tom Harmon. (On two-inch videotape, apparently transferred from film. Tape #583. Also transferred to videocassette)Features: Tom Harmon
Ca. 5-10 minute tape of UM's 1940 season opening victory over California. (Two-inch videotape apparently transferred from film. tape #584. Also transferred to videocassette.)
Ca. five minute clip from the dedication of Michigan Stadium in 1927. (Two-inch videotape apparently transferred from film. Tape #585.)

Footage of dedication ceremonies at the Beaumont Memorial on Mackinac Island commemorating Dr. William Beaumont, pioneer Michigan surgeon, includes series of speeches and shots of the Memorial building, former trading post of the Astor Fur Company.
Footage of dedication speeches and Memorial Building
Continues footage of Beaumont Memorial building and crowd at dedication ceremony.
Continues footage of dedication ceremony.
Continues footage of dedication ceremony.
Partial game footage from the UM vs Duke football game.
Film footage of the UM football squad posing for the official team photo. Features: Glen "Bo" Schembechler, UM-Ath.
