did.abstract: Film on Trinidad, a village on the Guaurabo River of Cuba founded in 1514, that retained the flavor of a 17th century Spanish town into the 1950s. It shows the industries, building styles, fiestas, and traditions maintained for nearly 400 years.

Film produced in cooperation with the UM Dept. of Mechanical Engineering on the development of plastics and the use of plastic in the automobile industry, includes footage of the injection molding process at Ford Motor Company's Saline plant.
A series of "trigger" films focusing on student instructor interaction as a variable in the teaching-learning process.
Film of UM Medical Center surgical procedure to correct an arteriosclerotic aneurysm of the left carotid bifurcation. Features: William Olsen, UM-Med. ; William Fry, UM-Med.

Depicts, with an Oriental flavor, the story of rice, the staple food of Japan and other Far Eastern countries. Shows traditional rice culture, including planting, cultivating, harvesting, cooking and eating.

A Dept. of Electrical Engineering film on the Systems Engineering Lab - Markhov Analysis/Que Analyzer System. A demonstration of research in man-machine interaction through graphic language. Features: Kekl B. Irani, UM-Eng.; Victor Wallace, UM-Eng.

did.unittitle: School Days: A Picture of Russian Education 1957
did.abstract: A Russian film on the Soviet's 10 year school program and concept of education. Describes the school days of Russian students from early grades through graduation. AVEC dubbed English translation, distributed for U.S. Comparative Education Society.
Film of UM Medical Center surgical procedure for treatment of duodenal ulcer. One of AVEC's best surgical films. Features: Richard Kraft, UM-Med.

did.unittitle: Sociological Investigation in the Social Science Classroom
did.abstract: Mid 1960's Plymouth (MI) High School teacher and class participate in unstaged discussion of social stereotypes based on physical appearance and race. A gifted teacher encourages critical thinking. Condensation of a week's class time.

Time lapse motion pictures of the sun's disc show major phenomena taking place, including sun spots, plagues, filaments, and prominences. Filmed at UM's McMath-Hulburt Observatory. First film to use telescope trained on sun over several years. Features: Oren C. Mohler, UM-Astron.

Filmed in cooperation with the UM McMath-Hulburt Observatory, this b/w film uses time-lapse cinematography to portray the different types of gaseous clouds which float above the solar surface. This was the first production of the AVEC.

Award winning film examines the discovery of the principle of metal stamping and looks at the development of the process from early 1900s to 1970s. Footage from Ford Motor Co. Woodhaven stamping plant shows the stamping process and early robotics. Features: George W. Williams, UM-TVC
Film about the "Sugarbush" of northeast Ann Arbor and preparation of maple syrup.

Film about the Baird Carillons in Burton Tower at UM. Footage of the casting of the bells in England, finishing and playing the bells at the foundry with shots of the bell "works" and installation of the carillon in Burton Tower in 1936. (b/w sil.)

physdesc.physfacet: 16mm film, b/w, silent, 00:6:02 @ 18 fps., Neg. # 128, Pos. # 73

did.abstract: An animated film illustrating the problems caused by urban racial polarization between predominantly black inner cities and predominantly white suburbs. A student film produced with the UM Economics Dept. and the Center for Afro-American Studies.

Film on life at the University of Michigan, footage of campus buildings, student activities, lecture and classroom scenes, Ann Arbor night life, homecoming and the International Student Center. Made in cooperation with the UM Alumni Association. Features: Alexander Ruthven; George Brown, UM-Eng.; George Uhlenbeck, UM-Physics; William Paton, UM-Bus

did.unittitle: Who Cares About the Huron River
did.abstract: A film on the history of development along the Huron River, focuses on issues of pollution, water management, and recreational use. Andrew Tugg shot the river footage. One of the early environmental awareness films.

did.unittitle: Who Cares About the Huron River
did.abstract: Features some of the local Watershed Council personalities of the time. Produced with the UM School of Public Health, School of Natural resources and the Huron River Watershed Council.

Rides and Pinholds.; Part three of a series of training films for amateur wrestlers features instruction by UM wrestling coach Cliff Keen on techniques for rides and pinholds. Features: Cliff Keen-UM wrestling

Escapes and Reversals.; Part two of a series of training films for amateur wrestlers features instruction by UM wrestling coach Cliff Keen on techniques for rides and pinholds. Features: Cliff Keen-UM wrestling

did.unittitle: School Days: A Picture of Russian Education 1957
did.abstract: A Russian film on the Soviet's 10 year school program and concept of education. Describes the school days of Russian students from early grades through graduation. AVEC dubbed English translation, distributed for U.S. Comparative Education Society.

Film produced for UM Extension Service and Detroit Edison, a training film for emergency personnel on safety measures for handling electrical powerlines and wires. An award winning film. More prints of this film were sold than any other AVEC title. Features: George W. Williams, UM-TVC
An Alumni Association sponsored film featuring scenes from UM campus and Ann Arbor including footage from 1930s, interviews with alumni who have returned to campus. Copy also at Series S. pos #3557
see also Series S pos. no. 3405

did.unittitle: Series A, Accent: A Michigan Report

scopecontent.p: Series A, "Accent: A Michigan Report" was produced from 1955 to 1961 as part of the University Television Hour. This series is a continuation of Series H under a new name.

did.abstract: Assistant Dean of UM Medical School discusses modern methods of medical education, admission requirements, and costs. Features: Wayne Whitaker, UM-Med.

Campbell discuses the results of the 1948 and 1952 presidential elections, and how parties will proceed in 1956 elections, looks at how and when voters make up their minds. Features: Angus Campbell, UM-ISR, Samuel Eldersveld, UM-Pol.
Two English professors discuss and demonstrate the teaching of writing to freshmen. Features: John Weiner, UM-Engl.; William Steinhoff, UM-Engl.
Three Michigan Daily editors and a photographer describe the policies of the student newspaper Features: Lee Marks, Debra Durchslag, Michigan Daily editors; Donald Pearce, UM-Engl.
UM geology professor describes Antarctica and reveals plans for his future expedition to polar continent. Features: James Zumberge, UM-Geol.
Quarles, visiting professor of history at UM, discusses the contributions of the Negro to American culture. Features: Benjamin Quarles

Program follows the growth of a forest over 50 year period, demonstrates use of tree ring machine and other techniques to measure and monitor forest growth. Features: Stephen Spurr, UM-SNR; James Zumberge, UM-Geol.

Angell, president of the Third World Congress of Sociology, relates his impressions of Iron Curtain sociologists and the state of the discipline there. Features: Robert Angell, UM-Pol.; Morris Janowitz, UM-Soc.
The story of Ann Arbor Books, the UM Press paperback line, looks at the impact of the paperback on publishing. Features: Fred D. Wieck, Dir. UM Press ; John Muehl, UM-Engl.
Color film on Ann Arbor's transformation from quiet university town to Saturday football mecca.
Former Studebaker - Packard executive is interviewed about the new UM Automotive Engineering Laboratory. Features: William H. Graves, Supt. UM-Auto. Eng. Lab.

Peek, recently returned from the Philippines, gives a first hand report on political and economic problems facing the Philippines and their effect on U.S. policy. Features: George Peek, UM-Pol.; Philip Taylor, UM-Pol.
Description of the UM International Center's work with foreign students on campus and in their native lands. Features: Janice Miller, UM-International Center
Scenes from the UM Gilbert and Sullivan Society's production of "Princess Ida." Features: Gilbert and Sullivan Society
William Campbell, 85-year-old Michigan inventor, is interviewed about his early days in aviation. Features: William Campbell, inventor; Al Barnes, newspaperman
Behind-the-scenes look at Wolverine Girls State, featuring sights and sounds of their political convention, address by Nancy Williams. Features: Nancy Williams
Look at how UM scientists will use Nike-Cajun rockets to study the upper atmosphere as part of the International Geophysical Year. Features: William Hanse, UM-ERI; James Zumberge, UM-Geol.
NYT reporter discusses the difficulties facing the Philippines following the death of President Magsaysay. Features: Robert Aura Smith, NYT ; George Peek, UM-Pol.
UM astronomers discuss their early sightings of Sputnik, and probable Russian launch techniques. Features: Edith Muller, UM-Astro. ; William Liller, UM-Astro.

Distinguished physicist and a mathematician familiar with Soviet science discuss recent Soviet technical advances and what it may mean for the future of civilization. Features: David Dennison, UM-Physics ; A. J. Lohwater, UM-Math

did.unittitle: Science Foundation: Better Teachers for Tomorrow's Scientists 1957
did.abstract: UM's unique "Academic Year Institute" that allows science teachers to return to school for advanced work. Features: Leigh C. Anderson, UM-Chem. ; A. J. Lohwater, UM-Math
A behind-the-scenes tour of a modern day exhibit museum. Features: Irving G. Reiman, Dir. UM Exhibit Museum

A Scientist Looks at Morality.; An informal discussion on the traditions of morality, focus on Angell's forthcoming book "Free Society and Moral Crisis." Features: Robert C. Angell, UM-Pol. ; Morris Janowitz, UM-Soc.
A film tour of the UM Undergraduate Library, the first university library devoted to the needs of undergraduates, "one of the most unusual buildings in the world." Features: Roberta Keniston, UM-UGLI

Your Social Security.; Eight part series on the Social Security System. In this program series host Cohen discusses the range of social insurance and public welfare programs generally grouped under the title "Social Security." Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; Fedele Fauri, UM-SW
Your Unemployment Insurance.; A look at the development of unemployment insurance and how it falls far short of the original intent. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; Fedele Fauri, UM-SW
Expanding Unemployment Insurance.; A discussion of proposals to expand coverage and benefits of unemployment insurance. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; William Haber, UM-Econ.
Your Old Age Insurance.; An examination of how our growing aged population poses new problems for the social security system. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW
The Big Questions.; Examines proposals to change the eligibility requirements and benefits of social security system. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; Robert Hamlin, HEW
Your Health Insurance.; Discusses problems of health insurance in the U.S., especially coverage for the aged and the poor. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; Carl H. Fisher, UM-Bus.
Public Welfare Programs.; This discussion of public assistance programs points up the wide gaps among states providing financial relief. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW; Fedele Fauri, UM-SW
The Future of Social Security.; Discusses the serious gaps in the social security system and looks at possible remedies. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW ; William Haber, UM-Econ.

A graphic survey of the vital role of water resources and education in the economic life of modern Michigan, features photographs of early college life in Michigan from the Michigan Historical Collections.
A report on the research facilities of the UM's Great Lakes Research Institute Features: John Ayers, UM-GLRI ; David Chandler, UM-Zool. ; James Zumberg, UM-Geol.
Glimpse of America as seen by the first settlers from paintings of John White at Roanoke in 1585.
A close-up view of a 22 wheeled, 2 story truck which will provide a unique visual survey of road conditions in Michigan. Features: William Housel, UM-Eng.
Administrators from Ann Arbor's Slausson Jr. High discuss presenting a student written operetta, scenes from the performance.
Eldersveld discusses his dual role as professor of political science and mayor of Ann Arbor. Features: Samuel Eldersveld, UM-Pol.; Arthur Eastman, UM-Engl.
Iglehart and Sawyer serve as jurors at show of paintings by UM artists. Features: Robert Iglehart, UM-Art ; Charles Sawyer, Dir. UM Museum of Art
A look at contemporary sculpture through the work of five UM artists. Features: Chet LaMore, UM-Art ; Robert Iglehart, UM-Art
The Nature of a Modern University.; The nature of a modern university is discussed by the dean of the UM College of Literature, Science, and the Arts Features: Roger Heyns, UM-Dean of LSU&A
Folksinger and professor tells the story of immigration through immigrant songs. Features: Neil Snortum, UM-Engl.
A landscape architect looks at the "downtown of tomorrow," the shopping mall. Features: William Johnson, UM-Landscape Arch.
The romance of the early days of motoring as seen in song, story, film, and historical photos. Features: Jay Bolt, UM-Eng. ; Neil Snortum, UM-Engl.
The opening of the Dearborn Center campus of the University of Michigan is presented and its innovative program is discussed. Features: William Stirton, UM-Dearborn
Look at citizen's political beliefs and voting behavior in the Detroit Area. Features: Daniel Katz, UM-Psych. ; Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.
Interview with new UM football coach Bump Elliot, includes clips of former UM football stars Tom Harmon, Ron Kramer and others. Features: Chalmers "Bump" Elliot, UM-Athl.

How the discovery of an ancient type of stage machinery enabled the duplication of an 18th century English stage setting in a UM Speech Dept. production of Sheridan's "The Rivals." Features: William Halstead, UM-Speech
UM geologist discusses the geological history and formation of some of Northern Michigan's scenic spots. Features: John Dorr, UM-Geol.
Two UM economists discuss the current and future problems of Michigan's economic growth. Features: Gardner Ackley, UM-Econ. ; William Haber, UM-Econ.
The basic law of physics that governs rocket propulsion is explained. Features: Samuel Krimm, UM-Physics

Arthur Milne, director of the UM International Center, discusses its program and the services it offers, a panel of international students discuss the problems international students face on campus. Features: Arthur Milne, UM-Int. Cntr.

Dr. Warren, the first director of the division of Medicine and Biology of the Atomic Energy Commission, discusses effects of atomic radiation on the human body and the difficulties in establishing safe levels of radiation exposure. Features: Shields Warren

Continues discussion by director of the Medicine and Biology division of the Atomic Energy Commission on the effects of atomic radiation on humans and the setting of radiation exposure standards. Features: Shields Warren
Photographs from the heyday of the lumberjack tell the story of lumbering in the lake states before 1900.
The story of the Michigan-Ohio boundary line dispute, with Michigan obtaining the Upper Peninsula as compensation for the loss of the "Toledo Strip."
After four years of study of world disarmament, Stassen offers a plan for nuclear inspection. Features: Harold Stassen
Stassen urges that U.S. foreign policy be determined by Christian philosophy and not by national self-interest. Features: Harold Stassen
The Population Explosion. Two UM professors discuss the dangers of expanded population to our way of life. Features: Marston Bates, UM-Zool. ; Arthur Eastman, UM-Engl.

Politics.; Chairmen of the Michigan Democratic and Republican parties draw on their experiences to give high school students information on careers in politics. Features: Neil Staebler; Lawrence Lindermer
Impact of the population explosion on American society is discussed by UM expert in population studies. Features: Ronald Freeman, UM-Soc.

did.unittitle: Sound of a Different School Bell 1960
did.abstract: Welsh and Rubin discuss the new teaching technology, teaching machines, television, film. Features: Robert Walsh, UM-Speech ; Gene Rubin, UM-CRLT
Examines what the laser is, looks at its current and potential uses. Features: Dan Spaulding ; Lloyd Cross

Interview and pottery demonstration by Hamada, Japan's leading folk potter and director of the national folk museum. He was on campus as part of the sesquicentennial celebration. (Color film.) Features: Hamada

scopecontent.p: Series B consists of individual programs of general interest broadcast under the title "Understanding Our World" (UOW). The series does include a few multi-part programs. The series was initially broadcast live over WOOD-TV, Grand Rapids, 1952-1953, and later recorded on film or tape and broadcast as part of the UM Television Hour, 1954-1982. The programs cover a wide variety of content, usually hosted by or featuring university faculty, but a number feature prominent visitors to campus such as Eleanor Roosevelt, Christiaan Barnard and Arthur Miller. The programs were thirty minutes long. Most were black and white, tough later programs recorded on videotape were sometimes done in color

did.unittitle: Life or Death for the Aleuts 1954-1955
did.abstract: Using film, slides and photographs taken on a UM sponsored expedition to the Aleutian Islands, Bank discusses the cultural development of the Aleuts and pressures on their population and society from white encroachment. Features: Ted Bank, Dir. UM Aleutian Expedition

Program looks at the work of the UM archeological expedition to the Aleutian Islands, giving viewers an idea of how an archeological exploration is carried out. Features: Ted Bank, Dir. UM Aleutian Expedition
An examination of the economic and strategic importance of the Bering Sea and the difficulty the U.S. faces in protecting the Aleutian Islands Features: Ted Bank, Dir. UM Aleutian Expedition

An inside look at the organizing and outfitting of a scientific archeological expedition, films and photographs help recount some of the experiences of the expedition, including film of the climbing of Mt. Sitka. Features: Ted Bank, Dir. UM Aleutian Expedition

Traces the changes in the control and distribution of pharmaceutical drugs from colonial times to the present, focuses on the introduction of state legislation and the beginning of pharmacy education in which UM pioneered. Features: Tom D. Rowe, UM-Pharm.

Experts from the International Conference on Nuclear Engineering held on the UM campus discuss prospects for peaceful use of nuclear energy, the vulnerability of cities to nuclear attack, and civil defense plans in the event of nuclear catastrophe. Features: F.J. Van Antwerpen; Clarence E. Larson; Oliver Townshend; Alton Donnell; John J. Grebe

Experts from the International Congress on Nuclear Engineering held on the UM campus discuss the problems of public information and censorship in relation to nuclear energy. Features: Stephen Withey, UM-ISR; Morse Salisbury; James Beckerly; Watson Davis; James Barkner

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: A six part series featuring highlights from a UM summer session course on "Women in the World Of Man."

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: This program is a panel discussion on the role of women in contemporary times. Features: Morris Janowitz, UM-Soc.; Harold Dorr, UM-Ed.; N. Edd Miller, UM-Ed; Mary C. Bromage.

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: White, president of Mills College, Oakland, Cal., opens with comments on women in higher education followed by panel discussion. Features: Marvin Niehuss, UM-V.P.; Helen Dodson, UM-Astron.; Algo D. Henderson, UM-Ed.; Lynn T. White

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: Janowitz leads his UM seminar in a panel discussion on the changes and conflicts in women's role in modern society. Features: Morris Janowitz, UM-Soc.

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: Curator of the Oriental Division of the UM Museum of Anthropology, discusses "Articles of Adornment" and displays rare items of women's clothing from around the world from the UM collection. Features: Kamer Aga-Oglu, UM Anthro. Museum; Frances Clark Sayers, children's author

The Dancer's Heritage; New York Tribune dance critic and a leading contemporary dancer discuss the history of dance and demonstrate the modern dance technique that has made America's dance the most progressive in the world. Features: Walter Terry; Myra Kinch

did.unittitle: Women in the World of Man 1954-1955
did.abstract: Leading New York abstractionist painter and lecturer on art theory presents highlights from her recent talk at UM titled "Women and Dimensions in Art" illustrated by some of her own paintings. Features: Irene Rice Pereira

The UM Baroque Trio, Mason on harpsichord, Hauenstein on flute and Mueller on oboe, plays music from the golden age of Bach. This program features a demonstration of the harpsichord. Features: Marilyn Mason, UM-Music; Nelson Hauenstein, UM-Music; Florian Mueller, UM-Music;

Films featuring the Women's International Hockey Championship tournament held at UM over Thanksgiving weekend 1954, Stewart explains how the game is played, The Irish National team is interviewed. Features: Helen Stewart, UM-Phy-Ed.

The University of Michigan Baroque Trio plays three Bach sonatas. This program features an analysis of the sonata format. Features: Marilyn Mason, UM-Music; Nelson Hauenstein, UM-Music; Florian Mueller, UM-Music
The UM Men's Glee Club performs under direction of Philip Duey, including a medley of UM songs. Features: Philip Duey, UM-Music
Peckham narrates the story of Alexander Henry's capture by Indians at Fort Mackinac in 1765. Features: Howard Peckham, UM-Hist.

Three specialists in the areas of auto needs, highway design, and aviation engineering display pictures of transportation needs definitely coming in the next 20 years and drawings of their conceptions of travel in the year 2000. Features: Aarre K. Lahti, UM-Arch.; J.P. Buckley; Peter Altman

Literature and the Arts; Haugh discusses four Michigan authors and their books, Walton explains how Michigan's folklore is seen in her various types of folk songs. Features: Donald Pearce, UM-Engl.; Robert Haugh, UM-Engl.; Ivan Walton, UM-Engl.

Arts and Crafts; Unusual Michigan hobbies are described on this program including the art of lapidary - cutting, polishing and faceting stone, wood carving, and a 72 foot painting depicting scenes from the artist's Michigan boyhood. Features: Kurt Neuman; Rev. A. Allison; Jacob Lunde

The University of Michigan Baroque Trio performs music of the Baroque Period. Program host Donald Pearce traces the history of the Baroque Period in art, literature, science, and politics. Features: Marilyn Mason, UM-Music; Nelson Hauenstein, UM-Music; Florian Mueller, UM-Music

Chairman of UM Political Science department and two Michigan elected officials discuss the workings of the two-party system. Features: James K. Pollock, UM-Pol.; Lt. Gov. Phil Hart; House Speaker Wade Van Valkenburg

Four leading Northern Michigan citizens, a UM-Regent, chairman of the Mackinac Bridge Authority, an official of the Cleveland Cliffs Mining Company, and Director of the Conservation Commission discuss the economic development of Northern Michigan. Features: J. Herbert Manistique; Prentiss Brown; Walter F. Gries; Gerald E. Eddy

President of the United Auto Workers Union discusses past and present labor policies, gives his views on the guaranteed annual wage, automation, and worker incentive. Features: William Haber, UM-Econ.; Walter Reuther, UAW

Fiddler Patrick Bonner of Beaver Island, folk singer Ed Vandenberg and the world famous Klompen Dancers from the Holland Tulip Time Festival entertain from the rich heritage of Michigan.(beginning damaged) Features: Ivan Walton, UM-Engl.; Patrick Bonner; Ed Vandenberg

Assistant Supervisor of the State Highway Department Lab explains how the lab tests the road building materials which go into the state's 108,000 miles of roads. Features: Donald Pearce, UM-English; Frank Legg
A special drama telling how Michigan acquired the Upper Peninsula through a decision of Michigan's first governor, Steven T. Mason, at the time of Michigan's admission to the Union.
The story of aircraft designing and testing by the use of new "mechanical brain" computers, film of guided missile takeoff and flight. Features: Robert M. Howe, UM-Eng.
A visual tour of atomic destruction combined with designs for buildings in this atomic age. Features: Bruce Johnston, UM-Eng.
Railroad expert reports, through pictures and models, on the latest developments in the science of railroading. Features: Clinton Heimbach, UM-Civ. Eng.
A political scientist examines the impact of atom-produced electricity on the world political scene. Features: Daniel Wit, UM-Pol.
Staff members of the UM Museum discuss and demonstrate the creation of life-like natural science exhibits. Features: Irving G. Reiman; Robert S. Butsch; William A. Lunk

A report on the military organization of Germany and Italy looks at how a military elite has in the past exercised great power in those countries, discusses how large, peace-time, standing armies could affect democracies. Features: Morris Janowitz, UM-Soc.; Richard LeBlond

Hatcher and V.P.s for academic affairs and finance discuss the development of the university and it mission, the quality of its faculty, how building construction is financed, and the need for increased funds to meet increased enrollment. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; Marvin Niehuss, UM-V.P.; Wilbur K. Pierpont, UM-V.P.

The University of Michigan Stanley Quartet performs music of Mozart in a special program of chamber music to mark the 200th anniversary of the composer's birth. Features: Clyde Thompson, UM-Music; Donald Pearce, UM-Engl.; Stanley Quartet

Economic Planning.; Director of the Foundation for Human Behavior and two Asian economists compare Asian and American economic development as part of a week long conference held at UM to promote "people to people" diplomacy. Features: Charles Remer, UM-Econ.; Samuel Hayes; V.K.R.V. Rao

Human Values.; Presidents of three Asian Universities discuss how the Asian contemplative spirit protects human values during the transition into industrial nations as part of a week long conference at UM to promote "people to people" diplomacy. Features: Charles Odegaard, UM-English; Robert Angell, UM-Pol.; Vidal Tan; Badher Djohan
Documentary on the UM sponsored "Fire College" surveys the activities of a typical state conference of firemen, including demonstrations of the newest devices such as the Geiger counter.
Documentary surveys the increasing interest in civic orchestras, features the Midland Spring Festival, the Northwest Michigan Symphony Orchestra, and the Jackson Symphony Orchestra.

Visiting UM professor of history discusses the contributions of the Negro to American culture through history and the world of art, part of show focuses on eight New York painters and features paintings and drawings by representative Negro artists. Features: Benjamin Quarles; Robert Iglehart, UM-Art

Focusing on research being done at the UM Automotive Engineering Laboratory, program looks at how gas turbine blades are made, and their application to modern jet aircraft and tomorrow's cars. Features: Richard Flinn, UM-Eng.
A conversation about the modern conception of the "welfare state," and its implications in American democracy. Features: William Haber, UM-Econ.; Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW
A dramatized case study showing the social worker in action and comment by three social work educators. Features: Fedele Fauri, UM-SW; Elanor G. Cranefield, UM-SW; David G. French, UM-SW
UM professor who attended the All-Soviet Mathematical Conference gives his personal impressions of Moscow and assesses the state of Soviet engineering and science. Features: A.J. Lohwater, UM-Math.

Two members of a special study group on the Soviet German Economy at the Center for International Studies at MIT give an in depth analysis of Soviet Germany's economy and way of life. Features: Wolfgang Stolper, UM-Econ.; Karl Roskamp, UM-Econ.

Program follows the growth of a tree plantation over fifty years, showing techniques used by foresters to predict forest development. Features demonstration of unique tree-ring machine to measure tree growth and other foresters tools. Features: Stephen H. Spurr, UM-SNR; James Zumberge, UM-Geol.

Program shown in U.S. and Greece to commemorate 100th anniversary of the death of Dionisios Solomos, the Greek national poet, features performance by the Michigan Singers and Greek-American dance groups. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; Warren E. Blake, UM-Class.; Maynard Klein

Analysis of the 1956 national election, emphasizing the importance of ticket-splitting in electing a President and Congress. Features: Angus Campbell, UM-Pol.; Warren Miller, UM-Pol.; Philip B. Taylor, UM-Pol.

Program looks at the revival of community theatres, guests from various groups discuss the way their theatres got started and the problems and rewards of working in community theatres. Features: Hugh Norton, UM-Speech

Deans of UM and Wayne State medical schools and Michigan Medical Society officials discuss the emergency conditions of medical education in Michigan. Features: A.C. Furstenberg, UM-Med.; Gordon Scott; Arch Walls; L. Fernald Foster

A look at Eskimo sculpture, a unique art expression of man's relationship to himself and the world around him, featuring works from the collection of Eugene Power. Features: John Bardach, UM-SNR; Thomas Larkin, UM-Art

Using photographs and slides from the 19th and 20th centuries, Eaton shows what bold new adventures in living modern architecture is creating, demonstrating how modern homes emphasize the "unity of living." Features: Leonard K. Eaton, UM-Arch.

Behind the scenes of an UM opera production: candid visits, via documentary film, of music and drama rehearsals, costume and scenery design, lighting and make-up. Features: Josef Blatt, UM-Music; Hugh Z. Norton, UM-Speech
Candid films and interviews from "inside the walls" of Jackson's State Prison of Southern Michigan, largest walled prison in the world. Features: William Barren; Gus Harrison

Michigan basketball coach looks at the Wolverines in action against Minnesota and Michigan State, and tells how to spot the fine points which make basketball the exciting game it is. Features: Bill Perigo, UM-Ath.

Analysis of voting behavior and why people take stands on important issues in a national election is revealed through results of a UM Survey Research Center study. Features: Warren Miller, UM-Pol.; George Peek, UM-Pol.
A conversation with the distinguished American composer and UM composer in residence, and a performance of his Quartet #7 by the Stanley Quartet. Features: Ross Lee Finney, UM-Music; Stanley Quartet

Burton Tower carillon, a UM percussion orchestra, and the UM Men's Glee Club provide an unusual juxtaposition of beloved Christmas traditions and contemporary imagination in music and story. Features: Percival Price, UM-Carillonneur; Guy Palazzola, UM-Art; Men's Glee Club

Roundtable discussion of political and economic problems facing Western Europe as seen by UM faculty members familiar with current conditions. Features: Henry Bretton, UM-Pol; George Peek, UM-Pol; Wolgan Stolper, UM-Econ; Preston Slosson, UM-Hist
Thomas, leader of the American socialist movement, reflects on his career, his socialist philosophy, and on world politics. Features: Norman Thomas; William Haber, UM-Econ.
A University biologist reports on a visit to an island paradise in the South Seas where he studied the land and its people. Features: Marston Bates, UM-Biology
Graves, distinguished English poet, critic, and novelist, talks about poets and poetry and reads from his own works. Features: Allan Seager, UM-English; Robert Graves

Sen. Paul Douglas of Illinois discusses the nature of politics and several of the current issues before Congress: economic recession and presidential disability. Features: Samuel Eldersveld, UM-Pol.; Sen. Paul H. Douglas

did.unittitle: Vivaldi: The Red Priest of Venice 1958-1959
did.abstract: Seldom heard sonatas by Antonio Vivaldi, Baroque composer, performed by the UM Baroque Trio. Features: Nelson Hauenstein, Florian Mueller, Marilyn Mason, Howard Rarig, all UM-Music; Baroque Trio
Eight outstanding high school students present their views on how modern education can meet the challenge of today's changing world.
Two specialists in water resources present a graphic survey of Michigan's water wealth, needs and problems. Features: Robert Dils, UM-SNR; Karl Lagler, UM-SNR
The procedures, problems and benefits of constitutional revision are analyzed by three UM political scientists. Features: Arthur W. Bromage, UM-Pol.; John W. Lederle, UM-Pol.; George Peek, UM-Pol.

A film visit to the General Motors Technical Center, a modern temple of steel, glass, and brick dedicated to research for a better tomorrow. Features: Leonard K. Eaton, UM-Arch.; Walter B. Sanders, UM-Arch.; John J. Cronin

Performances on lute, guitar, and basset horn highlight a look at the UM Stearns Collection, second largest collection of rare musical instruments in the United States. Features: William Stubbins, UM-Music; Robert Warner, UM-Music

Psychologist and chairman of UM Dept. of Military Science and Tactics analyze the indoctrination techniques used by the Chinese on American prisoners during the Korean War. Features: James McConnell, UM-Psych.; Ernest Woodman, UM-Mil. Sci.
Contemporary music by UM faculty composers, performed by the UM Woodwind Quintet. Features: Woodwind Quintet
Noted anthropologist and author comments on life in the United States today and tells how she came to be an anthropologist. Features: Margaret Mead

An unrehearsed meeting between two people, each of whom speaks a language the other has never heard, demonstrates how you can learn language without the aid of a translator. Features: Kenneth Pike, UM-English

Examines how modern scholarship has found in ancient letters and documents a valuable source of history, features documents from the Kelsey Museum and the Michigan Manuscript Collection of the University Library. Features: O.M. Pearl, UM-Classics

Chief of Federal Great Lakes Fisheries Investigations discusses the successful thirteen year war waged by the weapons of modern science against the sea lamprey, deadly and destructive Great Lakes invader. Features: Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.; James W. Moffett
Eleanor Roosevelt discusses present world problems. Features: Eleanor Roosevelt; Samuel Eldersveld, UM-Pol.
A fantastic performance by tiny cast iron balls illustrates the phenomena of "electrospherics" and "magnetoshperics" discovered by UM professor Moore. Features: A.D. Moore, UM-Eng.
Folk singer and English teacher, presents songs men sing while working, including lumberman's songs of Northern Michigan. Features: Niel Snortum, UM-Engl.
UM metallurgist shows the strain resistant properties of the metals used in your automobile. Features: Richard Flinn, UM-Eng.
Program examines the lands, resources, and ways of life of the four great regions of Alaska. Features: William Benninghoff, UM-Bot.; Karl Lagler, UM-SNR
Examples of common errors in presentation and interpretation of statistics help you evaluate charts, graphs, and survey figures. Features: Richard Remington, UM-SPH; Douglas Chapman, UM-SPH
Atomic energy, aphasia, and new kinds of art are surveyed in report on current research at UM. Features: J.B. Bullock, UM-Eng.; Harlan Bloomer, UM-Speech; Richard Jennings, UM-Art

Three Michigan artists --a writer, an operetta composer, and a painter-- show how the heritage and history of Michigan have provided rich material for their work. Features: Al Barnes; Cynthia Dodge; Edward Anthony
Three successful small manufacturers discuss the role of small business and the possibility of starting such a business today. Features: William Hoad, UM-Bus.
Thor Johnson, American conductor, airs his views on serious music in America today. Features: Gail Rector, UM-Musical Society; Thor Johnson

Former American consul for Peking, provides an exciting eye-witness account of the Chinese Communist 1950 takeover of the American consular property in China. Features: James Crump, UM-Far East. Lang.; Howard L. Boorman

Story of the development of our alphabet, from picture writing to present day is told and illustrated by two UM professors of design and an editor of the Middle English Dictionary. Features: Leonard Zamiska, UM-Arch.; Sherman Kuhn, UM-Eng.; Philip Davis, UM-Arch.
Saga of the American automobile, seen in song, story, film, and historical photos. Features: Jay Bolt, UM-Eng.; Neil Snortum, UM-English
UM President Harlan Hatcher reports on his 15,000 mile trip through Russia investigating the educational system of the Soviets. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.; Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.
An introduction to the world of mushrooms and mushroom hunting by the author of "Mushroom Hunters Field Guide." Features: Alexander Smith, UM-Bot.
A look at the Nobel prizewinning author, Boris Pasternak, through his life, his writings, and his correspondence with his American translator Eugene Kayden. Features: Eugene Kayden

Max Lerner, famous American man of letters, offers his views concerning the destiny of American civilization, the US-USSR power struggle, and the future of America as a world power. Features: Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.; Max Lerner
UM head football coach "Bump" Elliot charts his wing T offense and answers oft-raised criticisms of college athletics. Features: Chalmers "Bump" Elliot, UM-Ath.
Using models and photographs, Detroit city planner describes the new Detroit rising up at the waterfront. Features: Philip Youtz, UM-Arch; Charles Blessing
The story of the UM's newest research tool, an 85 foot parabolic radio telescope at Peach Mountain, Michigan. Features: Fred Haddock, UM-Astronomy
A UM population expert discusses the significance of family planning in determining the size of population and its effect on society. Features: Ronald Freedman, UM-Soc.
The chief English prosecutor at the Nuremberg Trials of German war criminals discusses the justice of that event. Features: Arthur Eastman, UM-English; Sir Hartley Shawcross

A talk with Dr. Sidney Chapman, famed research scientist and president of the scientific committee which headed the International Geophysical Year. Features: Sidney Chapman, UM-IST; Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.

An interview with Pres. Whitehouse of Albion College, on the 125th anniversary of the school, provides insight into the role of the independent, church related, liberal arts college. Features: Arthur Eastman, UM-English; William W. Whitehouse, Pres. Albion College

A Michigan Week special one hour documentary shot on location throughout the state honoring different nationality groups in Michigan. Features interviews with three generations of families from various ethnic groups. Features: Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.
Continues part 1. Features: Peter Gosling, UM-Geog.
UM composer discusses his life and work, including five years of study with Arnold Schoenberg. Features: Roberto Gerhard, UM-Music; Arthur Eastman, UM-Engl.

Ambassador Halm of Ghana and Michigan Gov. G. Mennen Williams discuss African problems and potentials on show hosted by Detroit City Councilman William Patrick Jr. Features: G. Mennen Williams; W.M.Q. Halm; William T. Patrick, Jr.

did.unittitle: Program for the Aged: Sen Wayne Morse 1960-1961
did.abstract: U.S. Senator Wayne Morse discusses the problems of health care for the aged and expansion of social security benefits. Features: Woodrow Hunter, UM-Geron.; Sen. Wayne Morse; Clark Tibbits, HEW
Representatives of industry, labor, and government discuss how the citizens of Michigan seek to create new jobs. Features: Gardner Ackley, UM-Econ.

Mukle, world renowned cellist and one of the first women to make a career as concert artist, discusses the struggles of women musicians in the Victorian Age, her association with suffragist Emmeline Pankhurst, and plays several selections. Features: Oliver Edel, UM-Music; Muy Mukle

The education a student receives at UM Law school is briefly sketched and then a federal judge, an English barrister, and a New York attorney discuss the difficult problems new lawyers will face in the next decade. Features: John Brown; Lord Hartley Shawcross; Ralph Carson

did.unittitle: Music from the University of Michigan 1960-1961
did.abstract: A final performance by the University of Michigan Symphony Band before their trip to Russia. Features: William D. Revelli, UM-Music; Symphony Band

Ayn Rand, noted novelist, philosopher, and controversial figure on the modern intellectual scene, offers her views on the current intellectual crisis in American society. Features: James Mc'Connell, UM-Psych.; Ayn Rand

Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs comments on U.S. policy toward African independence movements and on appeal of communist ideology in Africa. Features: G. Mennen Williams; Morris Bornstein, UM-Econ.
Three of the key health officials involved in unraveling the mystery of an outbreak of histoplasmosis in Milan, MI tell their story. Features: Horace Dodge, UM-Med.; Otto Engelke; John DeTar
Story of Winnebago Indians is reflected in the life of Mountain Wolf Woman as told to a UM anthropologist who was adopted into the tribe. Features: Nancy O. Lurie, UM-Anthro.
World renowned nuclear physicist comments on disarmament, civil defense, and the future of science at a special news conference. Features: J. Robert Oppenheimer

Professor Joseph Payne plays "Eskimo Arithmetic," counting in base five, with three youngsters and demonstrates new teaching methods emphasizing discovery over rote memorization. Features: Joseph Payne, UM-Ed.

Interview with Peace Corps Director Sargent Shriver, includes footage of John Kennedy's speech announcing Peace Corps and Shriver's talk to Corps volunteers trained at Michigan. Features: Sargent Shriver; Arthur Eastman, UM-Engl.
A documentary view of a twentieth century profession, the Group Worker examines this special type of social work. Features: Robert Vinter, UM-SW

did.unittitle: New Power: Nuclear Energy for Electricity 1962
did.abstract: Four outstanding experts explore the rapidly developing field of nuclear-fueled power generation. Features: William Kerr, UM-Eng.; Samuel Estep, UM-Law; James Campbell; Robert Hartwell
Film documentary of Peace Corps training program at the University of Michigan, and discussion by program leaders. Features: Robert Leetsma, UM-Ed.; Harold Dorr, UM
Ten part program hosted by Hugh Fleetwood, UM-Phil.

In this part UM faculty and state legislator discuss the communist threat, government loyalty-security programs and their impact on civil liberties. Features: Gilbert Bursley; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; John Searle, UM-Phil.; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist.

In this part University of Michigan faculty members discuss the nature and meaning of loyalty and disloyalty in a democratic nation. Features: Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Elton McNeil, UM-Psych.; John Searle, UM-Phil.,Stephen Tonsor, Hist.

University of Michigan faculty members investigate the range of problems affecting the rights, liberties and duties of the free press in America. Features: Ben Yablonky, UM-Jour.; John Searle, UM-Phil.; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist; Jerold Israel, UM-Law

University of Michigan faculty members examine the issue of church and state and offer their views on the nature and meaning of religious liberty and democratic freedom of religious conscience and expression. Features: Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Gerhard Lenski, UM-Soc.; John Searle, UM-Phil.; Stephen Tonsor

University of Michigan authorities discuss the civil rights and basic freedoms of the American worker and the responsibilities of government, management and labor unions. Features: Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist; Albert Steigerwalt

University of Michigan faculty authorities discuss academic freedom and academic responsibility as fundamental conditions of a free society. Features: Nicholas Kazarinof UM-Math.; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist.; Elton McNeil

University of Michigan faculty members consider progress and problems in the democratic achievement of personal freedom and equality for all American citizens. Features: Ralph Gibson, UM-Med; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist.

University of Michigan law professors examine the democratic guarantees of personal freedom and the right to safety and security of the individual against arbitrary action by government enforcement agencies. Features: Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law, Stephen Tonsor; Edmund Devine, UM-Law

A novelist and UM faculty members analyze the modern restriction on the democratic free enterprise of ideas and the major ideas involved in the public and private censorship of books, magazines, films, etc. (print damaged) Features: Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist.; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Earl Karr

Freedom and Conformity.; University of Michigan faculty authorities discuss the conflict between individual freedom and the American citizen's urgent search for security in a modern age of anxiety. Features: John Pollard, UM-Med.; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Stephen Tonsor, UM-Hist

did.unittitle: Law and the Man of Property 1962
did.abstract: Two University of Michigan law professors offer a close and revealing study of the legal meaning of ownership in the modern world. Features: Richard V. Wellman, UM-Law; Joseph Julin, UM-Law

A United States Information Agency instructor questions Peace Corps volunteers in training at the University of Michigan about the U.S. as he plays the role of well informed foreigners. Features: Charles Vetter

Five top women business executives describe the difficulties of women in the business world in an informal panel discussion. Features: John A. Hanson, UM-Class.; Virginia Allen; Rita Bolitho; Nancy Roman, Hettie Smith
A comparison is made between Russian and American systems of education by a University of Michigan professor of education and surprising similarities are pointed out. Features: William Medlin, UM-Ed.

A special film documentary on Frost's press conference and lecture at UM less than a year before he died. Frost reads his poem "Never Again Will Birds' Song Be the Same." [Sound quality is poor in some sections] Features: Robert Frost; Donald Hall

The development of the American woman from her underprivileged 19th century position to her active role in reform movements today is analyzed and illustrated. A suffragette is interviewed as are members of LWV, WCTU, Planned Parenthood, and HOME Features: Robert Blood, UM-Soc.; Mrs George C. Grimes

The Sentinels; A discussion of the increasing scope and responsibilities of America's military establishment with experts who have unique experiences working with the military in civilian capacities. Features: Elton McNeil, UM-Psych.; James K. Pollock, UM-Pol.; David Singer, UM-ISMRD

Memory transfer and cannibalism in flatworms, training flatworms to run mazes. UM scientists will discuss some new ideas about the nature of learning and memory based upon experiments conducted with flatworms. Features: Elton B. McNeill, UM-Psych; James McConnel, UM-Psych; John Bardach, UM Zool.

did.unittitle: Secretary of the Interior: Stewart Udall 1962-1963
did.abstract: Sec. of the Interior Udall is interviewed by professors from the UM School of Natural Resources. Features: Stewart Udall; Stanley Cain, UM-SNR; Stephen Spurr, UM-SNR

did.unittitle: Hard Work If You Can Get It 1962-1963
did.abstract: Peace Corps Program Officers for the Far East and West Africa programs discuss the different roles the Peace Corps plays: in the lives of individual volunteers, in the countries in which they serve, and in the domestic life of the U.S. Features: Arthur Mendel, UM-Hist.; Harold G. Tufty; John D. Rockefeller IV
Chief of Overseas Planning and Projects for the Peace Corps and UM history professor take a hard look at the Corps, past, present, and future. Features: Arthur Mendel, UM-Hist.; Warren Wiggins

Swithinback, a leading Antarctic scientist and explorer will discuss the explorations and discoveries in Antarctica as well current studies and research. Features: Charles Swithinback, UM-IST; Charles Kelly, UM-Geol.

UM School of Architecture and Design faculty member and fountain designer discards concrete structure and creates sculptural shapes in water. Features: Richard Jennings, UM-Arch.; Charles O'Donnell, UM-Engl.

The works, thoughts, and philosophy of a world renowned architect, Walter Breuer, are discussed by Breuer and chairman of the UM Department of Architecture. Features: Walter Saunders, UM-Arch.; Walter Breuer

Puppets and Puppeteers; The famous Bixby marionettes of Saline, Michigan join storyteller Mary Ann Stevenson in portraying the tale of "Jack and the Beanstalk." A visit backstage to see how the puppeteers manipulate the marionettes. Features: Mary Ann Stevenson; Meredith Bixby

A hopeful look at some grown-ups of tomorrow in the nation's inner city schools of today. Director of the Detroit chapter of the Great Cities Improvement Project discusses how the Project works with child, school and, community. Features: Henry Meyer, UM-SW; Carl Marburger
Harlan Hatcher, President of the University of Michigan describes his institution's present status to the people of the state. Features: Harlan Hatcher, UM-Pres.
The positive value of seatbelts are shown in a report of the research conducted by two UM Medical School professors. Features: Donald Huelke, UM-Med.; Paul Gikas, UM-Med.

Automation and Society.;Experts from the University of Michigan Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations and Bureau of Industrial Relations discuss the problems posed to the nation by automation. Features: Hyman Kornbluh, UM-ILIR, George S. Odiorne, UM-BIR, Arthur Mendel, UM-Hist.

Armament/Disarmament.; Political scientist and mathematical theorist present their views on the arms race and its place in world society. Features: Anatol Rapaport, UM-Math; Harold Jacobson, UM-Pol.; Arthur Mendel, UM-Hist.

Perception of Fear.; Internationally known UM expert on game theory examines international relations and the value of "game theory" in planning national strategy. Features: Anatol Rapaport, UM-Math; Arthur Mendel UM-Hist.

Mass v. Excellence.; Three UM scholars meet to debate "quality vs. quantity" in education, examining the pros and cons of establishing an intellectual elite. Features: Arnold S. Kaufman, UM-Phil.; Gerald F. Else, UM-Class.; Arthur Mendel, UM-Hist.

Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.; Sen. Hubert Humphrey and staff members of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency report on the founding of the agency, its mission, and the U.S. effort to ease world tension by planning for disarmament. Features: Elton B. McNeil, UM-Psych.; Hubert Humphrey; Thomas Lough; Bernard Bechoefer

An Effort From Many Quarters.; Efforts to control weaponry are viewed by UM psychologist Elton B. McNeil and representatives from government, industry, and private peace research groups. Features: Elton B. McNeil, UM-Psych.;

Four UM professors discuss and appraise the presidency of the late president John Fitzgerald Kennedy Features: Joseph Kallenback, UM-Law; Sanford Kadish, UM-Law; Bradford Perkins, UM-Hist; Arthur Eastman
U.S. Sec. of Labor discusses many significant labor issues of the 1960s during a press conference held on the UM campus. Features: Willard Wirtz, Sec. of Labor
Story of nine critical days in the Revolution and Washington's successful response. Features: Howard Peckham

Job Of Choice:; The guidance counselors role as he helps youths choose careers, some pressures involved, and what youths and parents can expect from counseling. Features: Edward Stasheff, UM-Speech; Delmont K. Byrn, UM-Ed.

The history, present educational aims, and future of Alabama's Tuskegee Institute. A discussion of the UM-Tuskegee cooperative exchange program and a performance by the Tuskegee choir. Features: N. Edd Miller, UM-VPAA; Russell Brown

A film critic and a film maker air their views on the role and problems of experimental film makers. A portion of an experimental film illustrates many of the points they discuss. Features: George Manupelli, UM-Art; Pauline Kael
Staff member of the UM Computing Center discusses how the computer works for us today and what it may make possible tomorrow. Features: Bernard Galler, UM
Editor of the Middle English Dictionary reports on its compilation at the University of Michigan. Features: John Reidy, UM-Engl.

A discussion of research results challenging the traditional picture of the creative scientist as a man off by himself, working in a specialized area and setting his own goals. Features: Frank M. Andrews, UM-ISR
Change and Excellence.; A study of the problems facing administrators of large educational institutions who try to maintain academic quality. Features: N. Edd Miller, UM-Ed.; William Haber, UM-Econ.
A study of an excavation into American prehistory and its significance. Including film of UM excavation of a Hopewell Indian site. Features: James B. Griffin, UM-Anthro.; Richard Flanders
Dance instructor and composer, discuss creating and performing modern dance. Features: Elizabeth Weil; William Malm, UM-Music
Training of people who work with emotionally disturbed kids, guidance and therapy at UM Fresh Air Camp. Features: Elton B. McNeill, UM-Psych.

did.unittitle: Civil Rights and Stained Glass Windows 1964-1965
did.abstract: Dir. of UM Office of Religious Affairs leads a discussion of the clergy's place in the civil rights movement. Hawkins, United Presbyterian, looks at responsibility of black and white clergy. Dotson describes his 1964 voter registration work. Features: N. Patrick Murray, UM Off. Rel. Aff.; Elder G. Hawkins; Paul Dotson
Two Peace Corps volunteers tell of their experiences in a small Ecuadorian village. Features: Robert and Flo Griffen

A discussion of the objectives of V.I.S.T.A. (Volunteers in Service to America) the domestic Peace Corps with VISTA official Richard Gerson, a UM student volunteer, and a Detroit anti-poverty official. Features: William E. Porter, UM-Jour.; Richard Gerson
Noted UM artist exhibits and discusses his personal collection of folk art from around the world. Features: Leonard Zamiska, UM-Art; William A. Lewis, UM-Art
Professor of French horn discusses its history, early horns are played. UM Quartet plays Mendelssohn. Features: Louis Stout, UM-Music; Jerry Bilik, UM-Music

A fresh and original look at how the gas buggy transformed America. Historic film footage, funny and nostalgic, takes us back to the turn of the century and the beginnings of the auto industry. Features: David L. Lewis, UM-Bus.

Psychiatrist, Clergyman and Counsel.; Ten part series hosted by Joseph Julin of the UM Law School. Representatives from various fields of university, professional, and religious life discuss the significance of justice in a democratic society. Features: Andrew Watson, UM-Med.; B.J. George,Jr., UM-Law; Rev. Russell M. Fuller; Joseph Julin, UM-Law

Justice and the Legislator.; Guest authorities from political, professional and academic life discuss the meaning of justice to democratic lawmakers. Features: William Pierce, UM-Law; Gerhart Weinberg, UM-Hist.; Stanley G. Thayer

Justice and the Judge.; Three UM Law School professors and Federal District Judge Wade McCree discuss the role of judges in meting out justice. Features: B.J. George, Jr., UM-Law; William B. Harvey, UM-Law; Wade McCree

Justice and the Doctor.; An examination of the relationship between law and medicine and the effect of law on medical progress. Features: William Smith, UM-Med; Richard Judge, UM-Med.; Marcus Plant, UM-Law
Justice and the Accused.; A consideration of the rights of the defendant under the criminal law. Features: B.J. George,Jr., UM-Law; Jerold Israel, UM-Law; Yale Kamisar, UM-Law
Justice and the Journalist.; A discussion of the relationship between justice and the free press. Features: William Porter, UM-Journ.; Dean Baker, UM-Jour.
Justice and the Reformer.; An examination of the significance of justice in the area of civil rights. Features: Robert Harris, UM-Pol.; William Harvey, UM-Pol.; Eugene Feingold, UM-Pol.
Justice and the Child.; An examination of the child in the administration of justice. Features: Tom Croxton, UM-SW; Elton B. McNeil, UM-Psych.; Andrew Watson, UM-Med.

Justice and the Worker.; A consideration of the areas of labor legislation and the impact of justice on the worker's position in the American economy. Features: Marcus Plant, UM-Law; Theodore St. Antoine, UM-Law; Russell Smith, UM-Law

Justice and the Lawyer.; A discussion of the relationship of justice to the education, training and, practice of the attorney. Features: Marcus Plant, UM-Law; Allan Smith, UM-Law; William Harvey, UM-Law

A beautiful and rarely performed medieval music drama, a story of the miraculous intervention of St. Nicholas, is presented in costume by the University of Michigan Consort of Voices, Viols and Historic Instruments directed by Robert Warner. Features: Clyde Thompson; Robert Warner, UM-Music; Consort of Voices, Viols and Historic Instruments
A progress report on the first classic Greek theater in the U.S. in Ypsilanti, Michigan. Features: Theodore Buttrey, UM-Class.; Alexis Solomis; Clara Owens

Director vs. Scholar:; Translation of the Greek tragedies for modern audiences poses a problem for both the director and the scholar, each having different viewpoints. Features: Theodore Buttrey, UM-Class.; Alexis Solomis

did.unittitle: Out of Time, Out of Place 1966
did.abstract: Out of Time, Out of Place:; A classical scholar and a theatre director conclude that the classic Greek plays can be translated for modern audiences. Features: Theodore Buttrey, UM-Class.; Alexis Solomis

The Speaker and the Word; Theatre is essentially the speaker and the word, success often depends on how well the word is spoken. Artistic director of Ypsilanti, Michigan Greek Theatre shows how meaning of play can be shaped by how words are spoken. Features: Theodore Buttrey, UM-Class.; Alexis Solomis
American politics at the local level is examined in a documentary about a Detroit city councilman's campaign for office. Features: Samuel Eldersveld, UM-Pol.; Mel Ravitz, Detroit city councilman

A dialogue on the churches' role in promoting civil rights. The film received a 1967 Mass Media Brotherhood Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Features: N. Patrick Murray, UM; Rev. N. Gordon Jones; Robert Spike; Hubert Locke
An explanation and demonstration of big band jazz with the University of Michigan Jazz Band. Features: Jazz Band
The 18 member UM Jazz Band performs near the site of the former Music School. Features: Richard Crawford, UM-Mus.; Jazz Band
A demonstration of how first graders from culturally different homes are taught standard English. Features: O.L. Chavarria-Aguilar, UM-Ling.; Elizabeth McEvoy

Three University of Michigan faculty members discuss the draft as a means of forming a military force and the methods of deferment. Features: Robert Angell, UM-Soc.; David Felbeck, UM-Eng.; Ross Wilhelm, UM-Bus.; Arthur Eastman

did.unittitle: Three Views on the Student as Human Being 1966
did.abstract: The effects of large educational institutions and modern teaching aids on the student. Features: Arthur Eastman, UM-Engl.; Carl Cohen, UM-Phil.; William Hays, UM-Dean; James O'Neill
Abortion:; A seminar on abortion - serious issue confronting society and legislatures. Features: J. Robert Wilson, UM-Med.; B.J. George, UM-Law; Fr. John Whitney Evans; Rev. Paul Light
Contraception:; A discussion of the laws and attitudes surrounding birth control. Features: Wayne Anderson, UM-Med.; B.J. George, UM-Law; Fr. Michael Donovan; Rev. Paul Light
Euthanasia:; A panel discussion of the moral and legal status of "mercy killing." Features: B.J. George, UM-Law; Roland Hiss, UM-Med.; Roger Howell; Donald Young; Msgr. John Bradley
Stasheff, an American television authority, discusses his recent role in establishing Israel's first television station. Features: Edward Stasheff, UM-Speech; Edgar Willis, UM-Speech

The development of children's literature, from Puritan books on the exemplary life for a child, to "Alice in Wonderland" which began a new trend toward imaginative literature for children. Features: Russell Bidlack, UM-Lib Sci.;

At over one thousand American colleges, students volunteer to tutor children to whom the public school cannot devote individual attention. Looks at programs at UCLA, Tuskegee, University of Michigan, and Youth Educational Services, Inc. Features: Morton Shaevitz, UM-Psych.
UM composer-in-residence discusses his composition and new music. Features: Ross Lee Finney, UM comp. in residence

Songs, dances, and interviews with the creators of an original student musical celebrating the 150th anniversary of the of the University of Michigan. Performances by MUSKET, the student musical company. Discusses the history of MUSKET. Features: Clyde Thompson, UM-Mus.

A look at the University of Michigan's Professional Theater Program which has turned Ann Arbor into a national theatre center. Features: Edgar Willis, UM-Speech; Robert Schnitzer, UM-PTP; Marcella Cisney, UM-PTP

The Dearborn campus of the University of Michigan is the nations first senior college, giving quality education to students and professional personnel from industry. Functioning of UM-Dearborn campus is explained and illustrated. Features: William Stirton, UM-VP; Edgar Willis, UM-Speech

A photographic study of man, his land, and the human misery they joined to create. Using Farm Security Administration photographs as illustrations, Miller examines the natural and economic factors that led to human misery. Features: Arthur Miller, UM-Law
Noted educator Dr. James B. Conant is interviewed on the future of public education in the U.S. Features: Joseph Julin, UM-Law; Stephen Withey, UM-ISR; James B. Conant

A look at one Michigan town, typical of small U.S. towns, and its fight to survive in 20th century urban America. Examines how UM School of Architecture and Design aided in Reed City's development. Features: Richard Morrow

did.unittitle: Arts, The: A Way of Life 1967-1968
did.abstract: Director of the Michigan State Council for the Arts documents its efforts to make the arts a meaningful and available contribution to the citizens of Michigan. Poet William Snodgrass interprets his work for high school students on MSCA program. Features: Karl Haas; William D. Snodgrass
A look at the government's role in the advancement of civil rights through economic channels. Features: Albert Wheeler, UM-Med; Richard Julin, UM-Law; Derrick Bell, HEW
A half hour color film visit to the world of a seven year old mental retardate. Winner of three awards.

A report on occupational health -- an area concerned with health hazards to U.S. workers. The award winning film looks at health problems in coal mines and industrial settings. Features: Harold Magnuson, UM-SPH

The strange, fascinating music of two young avant garde composers is played by a variety of musical instruments plus some unusual devices. Features: William Albright, UM-Music; Syd Hodkinson, UM-Music; Clyde Thompson, UM-Music

A color film of Dr. Barnard's news conference at the University of Michigan with comments by Dr. Kahn, UM thoracic surgeon. Features: Donald Kahn, UM-Med.; Frederic Hindley, Jr., UM-News; Christian Barnard

did.unittitle: To Work in a White World 1967-1968
did.abstract: Five Detroit high school seniors and two executives from Michigan Bell Telephone Co. get together to show how it feels to leave the ghetto for the first time. Features: George Higgins, UM-BIR

did.unittitle: Yea, Kids - Views on a Volunteer Project 1967-1968
did.abstract: How a University of Michigan student volunteer project keeps up with the times. Examines the process of evolution that keeps the project in touch with the rapidly changing school system and the Negro community which the project primarily serves.
Students discuss how music arrangement is taught at UM Features: Jerry Bilik, UM-Music
A linguistic look at race relations. Features: Robert Vinter, UM-SW; Albert Wheeler, UM-Med.
A picture and film study of poverty and welfare in the U.S. Includes film footage of the Detroit riot of 1967. Features: Howard Martin, UM-Speech

On Being Old.; A distinguished panel of active senior citizens discuss their philosophies of aging and the problems of continuing to lead socially active lives. Award winning program Features: Robert J. Havighurst; Cecelia O'Neill; Sidney L. Pressey

In a Sweet Country.; A medical doctor, a psychologist, and two psychiatrists discuss attitudes of the aged and the problems of adjustment to old age. Features: Maurice Linden; Robert Kastenbaum; Raymond Harris; Charles Gaitz
A look at how football was played in the 1920s and 1960s as seen through the eyes of Oosterbaan and Elliot. Features: Don Canham, UM-Ath.; Bennie Oosterbaan, UM-Ath.; Chalmers "Bump" Eliot, UM Ath.

Assistant dean of the UM Med Center, a speech rehabilitation expert, aphasia expert, and speech rehab researcher, all UM, discuss the nature and treatment of aphasia. Features: Beverly Payne, UM-Med.; Harlan Bloomer, UM-Speech; Elizabeth Wiig; Aaron Smith, UM-Speech
UM professor of ob-gyn and a practicing physician discuss natural childbirth. Features: John Gosling, UM-Med.; Irwin Chabon
An examination of the Detroit newspaper strike, 1967-68, and its implications for journalism. Features: John Stevens, UM-Journ.; William Porter, UM-Jour., A. H. Raskin, NYT
A new kind of treatment for elderly mental patients in a beautiful and moving film. Winner of an American Film Festival award. Features: Wilma Donahue, UM-Geron.; Dorothy Coons, UM-Geron.

The American businessman is assuming greater responsibility for upgrading economic life of the inner city and offering a non-violent answer to Black Power. Features: George Higgins, UM-BIR; George Odiorne, UM-BIR

did.unittitle: Inch, A Foot, A Mile, An 1968-1969
did.abstract: A student written, directed, and produced film about a student from a small Negro college who enters a unique program at the University of Michigan. Focuses on the UM Administrative Internship Program. Features: Edgar E. Willis, UM-Speech

A panel of teachers considers what Black history is and why it should be taught at all in our schools and universities. Features: William Porter, UM-Journ.; William Toll, UM-Hist.; Ronald Edmonds; Franklin Ferguson
The life of a University student is expressed in original music on a program written, produced, and directed by UM students. Features: Carolyn Delevitt; Bruce Fisher

The University of Michigan Professional Theatre Program Touring Company presents highlights from its Michigan tour, which created theatre magic for its young audience. Features: Stephen Dunning, UM-Speech; Professional Theater Program
Consumer and the Marketplace.; National authorities discuss the aging consumer and his problem of living on a fixed income in an inflated economy. Features: William R. Hutton
The Consumer as Target.; All consumers are targets of high pressure salesmanship but the aging consumer is more vulnerable. Experts discuss protection for the older person.

did.unittitle: Consumer Beware, Be Informed, Be Secure 1968-1969
did.abstract: Consumer Beware, Be Informed, Be Secure.; Experts point out the need for consumer education to protect against fraud and high pressure sales.
Allen, inventor of the Wff'n Proof game, discusses that and other academic games Features: Layman Allen, UM-Law

Housing the elderly involves more than providing them with four walls. An architect discusses housing needs of the elderly and residents of a housing project for the elderly are interviewed. Features: Leon Pastalan, UM-Arch.; William Donaghy, UM-Speech
A discussion and dramatization of student counseling services at the University of Michigan operated by and for the students. Features: James Shaw, UM-Dean LSA

Theatre West of Dayton, Ohio, a group of talented young black performers presents a bristling performance of black dance and drama. Young, the group's founder, discusses the meaning and philosophy of black theatre. Features: Clarence Young III

Theatre West of Dayton, Ohio, performs "The Afro-American Dance" and "The Oppressor in F Minor," two works by its founder and director Clarence Young III. Young discusses the relationship of Black Theatre to its audience. Features: Clarence Young III

did.unittitle: Storefront That Did Not Burn, The 1970
did.abstract: Story of a storefront health center that did not burn in the 1967 Detroit riot. Features: George D. Goodman, UM; Nancy Milio
Environmental law expert, resource planner, and law student discuss the emerging profession of environmental law. Features: John E. Bardach, UM-SNR; Joseph L. Sax, UM-Law; James Swan, UM-ISR
Portrait of Oosterbaan's career as UM football player and coach, with highlight footage. Features: Bennie Oosterbaan, UM-Ath.
Lukas discusses his career and award winning stories on drug addiction and the Chicago conspiracy trial. Features: John Stephens, UM-Jour.; Ben Yablonsky, UM-Jour.; J. Anthony Lukas, NYT

Author discusses his book on the closing of the Baker plant in Detroit and the effects of a factory closing on employees and their families. Features: Alfred Slote, UM-MMRC; Sidney Cobb, UM-ISR; Arthur Eastman
A filmed documentary on the University of Michigan environmental Teach-In, asking the question: do teach-ins work? Features: Brower, David, Godfrey Arthur, Slote Al, UM-TVC

did.unittitle: How to Put Your Husband Through College 1970
did.abstract: The problems and rewards of being a student wife are outlined by author Barbara Dembrodt based on her own experiences and research on contemporary married students. Features: William Donaghy, UM-Speech; Barbara Ream Dembrodt

A mathematician, a social scientist, and lawyer consider the impact of the computer on society -- both positive and negative. Features: Arthur Miller, UM-Law; Donald N. Michael, UM-Psych.; Bernard Galler, UM-Comp.
The computer's encroachment on rights of free speech, assembly, and privacy. Features: Arthur R. Miller, UM Law

Four professors examine the role of the computer in the election process and its challenge to the radio and TV press. Features: Warren E. Miller, UM-Pol. Sci.; Bernard Galler, UM-Comp.; Ben Yablonky, UM; Arthur Miller
A diverse panel of national authorities on the study and treatment of drug abuse offers fresh insights into the current drug scene. Features: John G. Pollard, UM-Psych.

A number of University of Michigan faculty members discuss the classroom and research side of the university in the wake of student unrest, the BAM Strike. This was the broadcast version of the program. Produced for the University Relations Office. Features: Gardner Ackley, Theodore Buttrey, Merle Crawford, Charles Davis, Harry Edwards, Sam Warner
An earlier version of the program that was not broadcast. This version includes some footage of activities during the BAM strike.

Why Drugs Now; UM Medical School professors share their personal insights and reactions to America's drug problem, providing current information on reasons for its growth. Features: John Pollard, UM-Med.; Robert Green, UM-Med.
Pot; An examination of some myths about marijuana and the complex social, psychological, and legal issues. Features: John Pollard, UM-Med.; Robert Green, UM-Med.
The Not So Simple Cop-Out; Three part series, psychiatrist and internal medicine specialist discuss the drug culture and its effect on society. Features: John Pollard, UM-Med.; Richard Green, UM-Med.
A judge, a law professor, and a psychiatrist consider whether American courts dispense justice equally. Features: Arthur Miller, UM-Law; Monica Blumenthal, UM-Psych; Judge George Crockett, Jr.
Jerry Bilik, UM composer in residence, discusses his work. Features: Dwight Stevenson, UM-Eng.; Jerry Bilik, UM-Music
Examines the role of the cicada in nature's cycle. Features: Thomas F. Moore, UM-Zool.

did.unittitle: Mr. Smith, Your Kid's Taking Drugs 1971
did.abstract: Social worker and board member of Ann Arbor's Ozone House, discusses what parents can do when they discover that their children are taking drugs. Features: Gayl Ness, UM-Soc.; Gus Leinbach

A group of youngsters underachieving in Flint high schools are doing well at the Flint campus of the University of Michigan. They tell why. Features: Gayl Ness, UM-Soc.; William Moran, Chancellor UM-Flint
Three UM-Dearborn students discuss the meaning of urban education. Features: Leonard Goodall, UM-Dearborn Chancellor; Bernard Klein; Gayl Ness, UM-Soc.

did.unittitle: Open Mind, The: Talk With Margaret Mead 1972
did.abstract: Noted anthropologist, author, and critic of the current world scene offers her views on topics ranging from women's liberation to the Vietnam War. Features: Gayl Ness, UM-Soc.; Margaret Mead

With a Little Help; Four educators discuss the special needs of gifted children in the regular classroom, and examine a private school with its open classroom format as one alternative. Features: Percy Bates, UM-Ed.; Warren Ketcham, UM-Ed.
A Teacher Affects Eternity; Two outstanding teachers describe how they motivate and stimulate students. Features: Percy Bates, UM-Ed.; William Stapp, UM-SNR

A panel including the former secretary of HEW and the current chairman of the White House Conference on Aging assess present and proposed policies as they influence the lives of the aging and analyze the political impact of the aging. Features: Wilbur Cohen, UM-SW; Arthur Fleming, HEW; Gayl Ness, UM-Soc.

A documentary film recording a project designed to train confused and disordered elderly people for independent endeavors. Looks at an experiment in milieu therapy at Ypsilanti (Michigan) State Hospital.

From Big Ten football and commencement exercises, to scientific research and cultural events, this fast paced documentary surveys what the University of Michigan means to the state of Michigan. Features: Richard Couch, UM-Eng.; Alfred Storey, UM-Ext.; Irving Feller, UM-Med.
Black child psychiatrist Dr. James Comer discusses black needs and white needs as human needs. Features: Theodore Buttery, UM-Class.; James Comer
Miller discusses his new play Up From Paradise and current problems plaguing Broadway. Features: Arthur Miller

Francois Giroud; France's most influential woman journalist describes the transition from being a press critic of her country's government to a member of that same government. Features: Charles Eisendrath, UM-Journ.; Francois Giroud; Bonnie Angelo, Time Magazine

Alfred Balk.; Interview with Balk, publisher of Atlas World Press Review, provides a panoramic look at the press outside the U.S. from a man who collects it. Features: Charles Eisendrath, UM-Jour.; Alfred Balk
Arnold Gingrich; Three part series on noted journalists and the magazines they shaped. This segment looks at the story of Esquire Magazine. Features: Arnold Gingrich
Six UM students who worked as summer interns in government and business discuss what they saw and learned. Features: Marilyn Young, UM-Res. Col.

Two part documentary on a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers program to investigate winter navigation on the Great Lakes. This segment examines why a year-long shipping season in the Great Lakes is necessary.
Looks at the details of making the Great Lakes navigable during ice-jammed winter months as part of a federal program to expand the shipping season on the Great Lakes.
Heller discusses his novels and experiences as a writer, particularly his latest work, "Something Happened." Features: Joseph Heller,; John W. Aldridge, UM Engl.
A look at the French horn and one of the world's largest private collections of horns. Features: Jerry Bilik, UM-Music; Louis Stout, UM-Music
Follows artist from studio to site in development of outdoor art, discusses importance of public art. Features: Richard Hunt; Bret Waller, UM-Art

Genesis of the Art.; Four part series on the history and techniques of film making. This segment looks at the early development of the motion picture, the genesis and evolution of an art form. Features: Frank Beaver, UM-Speech

Glance at Technique.; A special film designed to expose beginning filmmakers to the basic film techniques. The Master Scene concept is shown and then reshown with commentary on the elements of filmmaking. Features: Frank Beaver, UM-Speech
Filmmaker.: The Visual Artist; Two student films demonstrate how beginning filmmakers must rely on visual images to convey cinematic messages. Features: Frank Beaver, UM-Speech

The Screenwriter.; Interview with screenwriter Rob Thompson about the role of the screenwriter today in the development and production of a major motion picture. Clip from film which deals with the making of "B" westerns in the 1930s. Features: Frank Beaver, UM-Speech
McGuigan discusses her book on Metternich and the Duchess, commenting on sex and politics in the 19th century. Features: Dorothy Gies McGuigan, author; Charles Eisendrath, UM-Jour.
Hawaiian dance, music and chanted poems. Features: Judith Becker, UM-Music; Adelaide Suits, AA dance inst.
Members of the Trinidad Tripoli Steel Drum Band demonstrate the making and tuning of a steel drum, and perform classical, jazz, and calypso numbers. Features: Vera Embree, UM-Music; Hugh Borde
An interview with author of "Cry the Beloved Country," Paton discusses his novels and South Africa. Features: Alan Paton; Lemuel Johnson, UM-Engl.; Wesley Rae, UM-Flint

A look at the health problems of inmates and the quality of medical care at the State Prison of Southern Michigan, featuring on location interviews with prison staff and inmates and film of prison medical facilities. Features: Jay Harness, UM-Med.

did.unittitle: To Die With Dignity: To Live With Grief 1977-1978
did.abstract: An unusual series of self-portraits that may help us cope with death that is always with us in life. A terminally ill leukemia patient, a physician, a minister, and parents who lost a son discuss their experiences in dealing with death. Features: May Votaw, UM-Med.
A look at how music is used to enhance film, Dapogny plays some of the classic film stings that we traditionally associate with the chase. Features: James Dapogny, UM-Music; George Burt, UM-Music

Three men who pioneered in the field of adult education discuss their experiences in the field and the outlook for the future. Features: Bonaro Overstreet; Howard McCluskey, UM-Ed; Edward Soop, UM-Ext.

did.unittitle: Songs From the Soul: The Negro Spiritual 1977-1978
did.abstract: Recital of spirituals conducted by Jessye. Features: Eva Jessye; Willis Patterson, UM-Music
Prevention, control, and prosecution of computer crime. Features: Robert Iglehart, UM-Art
Kuhn discusses her Gray Panther Network, senior activism, and her various projects. Features: Maggie Kuhn; Carol Hollenshead, UM-Geront.
UM Tuba and Euphonium Ensemble performs three works. Features: UM Tuba and Euphonium Ensemble; Abe Torchinsky, UM-Music
Eleven part "magazine" program with short features on events, personalities and institutions of interest.
